century, Charles F. Kettering. Kettering was an exceedingly diffi- cult man, and also a man who

disregarded every single organizational rule. Yet his inven- tions, from the self-starter to the

redesign of the diesel engine, were of major importance. Sloan offered to set up Kettering as an

independent researcher. But Kettering wanted to be vice-president and a “big businessman.” Sloan

gave in, but the moment Kettering re- tired, the job was redesigned—from “resident genius” to

manager of a large research laboratory.

The design of a job has to start out with the task, but it also has to be a design that

can accommodate people with different temperaments, habits, and behavior patterns. This is

a major reason why managerial jobs ought to be designed big rather than small. A job has to be big

enough so that a good man can find within it his own satisfaction and achieve- ment, his own way

and method of working.

The Catholic Church offers an instructive lesson. The basic manager within the Catho- lic Church is

the bishop. It has long been the custom to rotate temperaments in filling a bishop’s See. If the

incumbent is a pastor, concerned primarily with the care of souls, he may be succeeded by a

theologian or by an administrator. In turn, a first-rate administra- tor is likely to be succeeded by a

man whose main emphasis is on his priestly function, and so on. The Catholic Church learned long

ago that the three qualifications—those of pastor, theologian, and administrator—are unlikely fo be

found in one person. Yet all three are needed to keep a diocese alive. Hence the bishop’s job is

designed very big in- deed—big enough for a good man to make of it what suits him. And the

standard of accomplishment is set by rotating the temperaments that occupy the See in succession.

See Sloan’s book, My Years with General Motors.

“A job should be small enough so that a good man can get his arms around it” is a

common saying. It is the wrong rule. “A job should be specific enough so that a good man

can go to work on it, but so big that he can’t get his arms around it” is the right rule.

“Style” should never be a consideration, either in designing a managerial job or in fill- ing it. The

only requirement of a managerial job, and the only test of the incumbent, is performance. Every

organization needs a clear understanding of the kind of behavior that is not acceptable. There must

be a clear definition of the nonpermissible action, especially toward people, whether inside the

business, i.e., employees, or outside, i,e., suppliers and customers. But within these limits a man

should have the fullest freedom to do the job the way it best suits his temperament and personality.

“Style” is packaging. The only substance is performance.

Job Structure and Personality

The abuse of titles and the “widow-maker” job relate closely to one of the most hotly de- bated

issues with respect to managerial jobs and managerial structure: Should the organi- zation be

structured so that jobs fit people? Or should the organization be “functional,” with people fitted to

jobs?

21 SEPTEMBER

“Widow-Maker” Positions

A.widow-maker position is a job that defeats

two competent people in a row.

“Widow-maker” is the term that nineteenth-century New England

shipbuilders used to describe a well-built new ship that still man-aged to have

two fatal accidents in a row. Instead of attempting to fix the

problems with the ship, they immediately broke it up to prevent another

ac-cident from occurring. In organizations, a widow-maker is a job that

defeats two competent people in a row. It will almost certainly defeat

Athird one, no matter how competent. The only thing to do is to abolish the

widow-maker position and restructure the work. Widow-makers typically

appear when an organization experiences rapid growth or rapid change. I

have since seen this phenomenon in a lot of organizations—for example,

in a university that within ten years had moved from being primarily an

under-graduate teaching institution to becoming a major research

university. That killed off two excellent people who took on the

presidency as it had been structured the old way, and by the way, any

number of deans—again, these positions could be filled successfully only

after the university had re-structured itself thoroughly.

The “widow-maker” job is usually the result of accident. One person

who somehow combined temperamental characteristics that are not usu-

ally found in one person created the job and acquitted himself or herself

well. In other words, what looked like a logical job was an accident of

per-sonality rather than the result of a genuine function. But one cannot

re-place personality.

ACTION POINT:

Is there a “widow-maker” position in your organization?

Either restructure the position or eliminate it.

People Decisions (Corpedia Online Program)

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

华为：让40岁的人离开，是最大的慈悲

前几天和一个创业有几年的朋友聊天，朋友说她计划观点一个研发中心，大约有十几个人。我有点唏

嘘。

不过，项目已经结束了，关掉也算正常。毕竟，剩下的运营需要的人员会比较少，而且，需要的人员

架构也和研发团队区别挺大。

第二天，我和一个共同的朋友聊天。这个朋友也算一个创业者，她的第一反应是：那些人跟了她那么

就久，怎么就要解散呀？

看到这个回复，我久久没有反应。我想的是另外一个问题。

在商业环境下，我们有项目，持续从几天到几个月到几年都有；也有公司，存活从几个月到几年到97

年都有；也有各种其他的复杂组合形式，可能是几分钟，也可能是很久。对于所有的商业合作来说，

我们的生命大多是超过它的。毕竟，我们的生命短则四五十年，长则上百年。

这也就意味着，商业合作结束后，我们会分开。或者赚钱后分钱分手，或者赔钱后大家结算一下分

手。或者好合好散，或者大闹一场，对簿公堂。最后还是散了。也就这样。

不管如何散，总之是会散的。这就是商业的宿命。

在商业结束之前，在商业进行之中，参与其中的个体也可能（可以）随时离开，或者主动，或者被

动。大多都是各种考量。

每个个体都有选择的自由，每个商业主体也有选择的自由。个人在什么时候应该离开？商业在什么时

候会要求人离开？这是一个很有智慧的事情。

很久很久以前，有一个传说，说的是华为的故事。华为被传有个“政策”是“辞退40岁的员工”。这个看

起来很冷血。可是，我认为这是华为对员工最大的仁慈。

不管你可以举多少40岁还年富力强的个案，40岁的人在工作精力、时间以及很多方面都开始减弱。

正常情况下，40岁的人孩子、家人也一堆了，正是上有老下有小的时候，精力也不能更多地花在工作

上。让这些人在关键岗位上则会影响整个公司的顺畅前行。

网上一个主流的话题是，员工为华为贡献了青春，到了40岁了，华为把员工一脚踢出去了，这个合适

么？这是一个表面上是一个道德问题。其本质是一个管理问题。

假设一个员工30岁进入华为，40岁离开，为华为服务10年。普通技术人员，按华为现行机制，10年间

大概可以拿到700-900万的薪水。如果离职的话，不管是被辞退，还是主动辞职，大概还可以拿到100

万+的离职安置金。

10年的时间，在华为这样的大厂，一个普通的技术人员大概可以磨砺出比较好的技术，或者在某个领

域比较突出。而且，也会有丰富的协作经验。所以，这些人在离职后，在一切企业还是有很强的竞争

力的。

那么，这些是肯定离开华为么？其实并不是，每4年一次的审核，还是有一些人会留下来的，只是这些

留下来的人，可能会有岗位调整，比如顾问岗，技术支持岗等。

其实，即使华为不要求他们离开，还是会有一些人主动离开，毕竟，40岁的人，社会阅历丰富了，技

术也成熟了，人际关系也熟练了。对于那些有想法的人来说，这是最佳的创业时机，为什么不趁这时

出去创业呢？还可以得到华为同事的一些支持。手头的那些现金，也可以让你有一个比较好的创业起

点。

如果你是那种寻求自我的人呢?几百万的现金，可以通过一些安全的理财产品，获得一个相对安全的收

益。这些收益，虽然不足以让你过上奢华的生活，普通生活还是可以的。

至少你可以选择自己喜欢的生活。

对于这些员工的离开，其实华为也有自己的收益和损失。华为的损失最主要的是熟练员工的缺失，不

过，对于有良好的培训机制的华为来说，这个可以忽略。

华为的收益是什么呢？就是可以让华为保持持续的战斗力和活力。而这个是华为这样的公司非常需要

的。

其实，这里还有一个隐藏的收益，这个我在网上没有查到，不过，德鲁克说到了，这就是高龄管理层

决策的问题。

当大部分员工在40岁以下，并且绝大多数管理层低于60岁时，可以有效避免决策者做出自己看不到结

果的决策。这样，决策者在决策过程中会更加用心。而华为也就更稳定发展了。

让40岁的员工离开华为，这个决定，不论对于华为涞水，还是对于每一个普通的华为员工来说，都是

一个最佳的选择。10年的华为生涯，至少你可以获得一个选择的机会，选择自己喜欢、期待的生活方

式，而这个，我认为是最大的一种仁慈。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

22 SEPTEMBER

Overage Executives

Stay out of decisions if one won’t be around to help bail out the organization.

Stay out of: vt. 置身于……之外

bail out:n. 跳伞；保释；舀出 parachute jump, release on bail

be around to:n. 来访；露面 show oneself, show up

An employer should have in place a policy for the over-sixties in managerial and professional ranks.

The basic rule, and one that should be clearly established and firmly enforced, is that people

beyond their early sixties should ease out of major managerial responsibilities.

It is a sensible rule for anyone, and not only for the executive, to stay out of decisions if one won’t

be around to help bail out the company when the decisions cause trouble a few years down the

road—as most of them do.

The older executive should move into work one performs on one’s own rather than be the “boss.”

This way, he or she specializes and concentrates on one major contribution, advises, teaches, sets

standards, and resolves conflicts, rather than works as a “manager.”

The Japanese have “counselors,” and they work very effectively, sometimes well into their eighties.

ACTION POINT:

Develop a retirement policy for senior executives.

Make sure these executives are not the sole decision-makers in decisions whose outcomes will

occur beyond the tenure of these executives.

sole：only; single 仅有的；唯一的

outcome：the result or effect of an action or event 结果；效果

tenure：the period of time when sb holds an important job, especially a political one; the act of holding an important job

（尤指重要政治职务的）任期，任职

The Frontiers of Management

22 SEPTEMBER

Overage Executives

Stay out of decisions if one won’t be around to help bail out

the organization.

An employer should have in place a policy for the over-sixties in mana-

gerial and professional ranks. The basic rule, and one that should be clearly

established and firmly enforced, is that people beyond their early sixties

should ease out of major managerial responsibilities. It is a sensible rule for

anyone, and not only for the executive, to stay out of decisions if one won’t

be around to help bail out the company when the decisions cause trouble

Afew years down the road—as most of them do. The older ex-ecutive should

move into work one performs on one’s own rather than be the “boss.” This

way, he or she specializes and concentrates on one major contribution,

advises, teaches, sets standards, and resolves conflicts, rather than works as

A“manager.” The Japanese have “counselors,” and they work

very effectively, sometimes well into their eighties.

ACTION POINT:

Develop a retirement policy for senior executives. Make

sure these executives are not the sole decision-makers in decisions whose

outcomes will occur beyond the tenure of these executives.

The Frontiers of Management

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

你为什么找不到男朋友

我有一个群，群里人不多，有男有女，有已婚的，有未婚的，未婚的大多没有男朋友。

这里群里讨论的话题很飘逸，每天都在各个话题之间切换。只是有一个特色：很多话题都会以单身女

生的世纪之问结尾：我为什么找不到男朋友。

这确实是一个世纪之问，我们每一次线下活动，只好进入开放交流阶段，不管是讨论宏观经济，还是

讨论健身、美食，最后都会不由自主地进入一个话题：为什么那么多女生单身。

是呀，为什么那么多女生单身呢？按国家宏观数据，同龄的男生比女生多，按这个逻辑，应该是大把

的男生找不到女朋友才对呀。为什么身边什么乱七八糟的男生都不缺女朋友，而很多即使很优秀的女

生也是孑孑茕立、形影相吊？

是他们经济条件好了，不愿意找么？好像也不是，有些女生甚至会花一些钱去相亲网站去找对象，也

会让朋友介绍，也会接受朋友的介绍。

可是，现实就是，她们还是单着，而且，看起来会一直单下去。

为什么呢？

有一次我问一个女生，女生是81年的，容颜姣好，我见犹怜。我问她：“你要找什么样的男朋友呀？”

这个女生回答说：“男的，活的”。

太模糊了，我又追问：“说具体点，这样的人太多了！”

然后她脱口而出：“活的有男人样的”。

我看了看她，沉默了。

有一个91年的女生，有一次和我聊一个事情。聊完后，她突然和我讲她的故事，她在世纪佳缘上的故

事。她在讲故事时一副委屈的样子。她说，我已经设置了很严格的过滤条件呀，世纪佳缘老给我推荐

一些很垃圾的男人，我觉得他们就想骗我的钱。

我说，你都设置了什么条件呀。她说，有年龄、学历、收入、身高等等等。

我问她：“有性别么？”

她瞪了我一眼，走了。

很早以前，我也会用QQ聊天，QQ聊天可以搜陌生人，我们搜模式人时，可以用一些过滤条件：城

市、性别、是否有摄像头、年龄等等等等。男生喜欢的一个游戏，就是通过这些过滤条件加一些人，

然后聊天。据说，这样可以很快交到朋友。

之后的社交软件也基本是这样一个套路：通过一堆条件来过滤，最后选出“最适合你的朋友”，让你们

去交朋友。

这时一个大数据时代，微信的日活已经超过10亿了，各种社交软件也都是上亿的数据，作为一个女

生，作为一个随时可以访问上亿社交数据的女生，作为一个可以随时通过过滤条件选出几百万人的一

个女生，居然找不到合适的人。

这些女生，每每刷半天这种社交（婚恋）软件后，就扔到一边，找个地方去抱怨自己的单身，自己的

孤独。

好像那个日活10亿的微信都没法给自己提供一个自己理想的男朋友。

这是为什么呢？

男朋友，指的是有恋爱关系的男性朋友，通常是对女生讲的。正常来说，对于一个女生，只要是男

生，就可以做男朋友。在没有大数据之前，我们通过肉眼来判断：这个人还不错。

在接触中，我们会逐渐发现，原来他还是个大学生，原来他还是一个学霸，原来他抽烟，原来他英语

很好，他生在海边居然不会游泳……

在一天天接触中，我们逐渐了解，然后两个人或者结婚，或者分手，至少谈了一次恋爱。

现在有了大数据，我们可以在几万、几十万、几百万、几千万、几亿人中选择一个人，这时，你就会

设置一些条件：不抽烟、不喝酒、身高不低于180、硕士以上学历、985等等等等。

女生的每一个条件都有很多道理，问题时，这些条件真的有意义么？

这些条件真的有意义么？

抽烟影响你婚姻的幸福么？

身高会影响你婚姻的幸福么？

985毕业，会影响你婚姻的幸福么？

这些条件有意义的可能性有多大？

“我不希望我的孩子太矮，所以我要求对方要高一些”

“我希望对方可以教孩子一些学科，所以希望对方985学校毕业”

这些和爱情、婚姻都无关地铁条件，真的是你想要的么？

大数据可以轻松为我们选择出任何条件的人，而真正的问题是，当你提出哪些无意义的问题时，你其

实在心中种下了一个不可能。

你需要的其实只是恋爱、结婚，如果你的目的是这样的，那么你应该做的是，看到那个你喜欢的男

生，走过去，然后说：“你好，我可以坐在你身边么？”

然后慢慢了解他。 而不是相反。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

23 SEPTEMBER

Controls, Control, and Management

The probability of an event’s being meaningful is a much more important datum than the event

itself.

We are rapidly acquiring great capacity to design controls in business and in other social

institutions, based on a great improvement in techniques, especially the ability to process and

analyze large masses of data very fast. What does this mean for “control”? Especially, what are the

requirements for these greatly improved controls to give better control to management? For, in the

task of a manager, controls are purely a means to an end; the end is control. If we deal with a

human being in a social insti-tution, controls must become personal motivation that leads to

control. A translation is required before the information yielded by the controls can become

grounds for action—the translation of one kind of information into another, which we call

perception. In the social institution there is a second complexity, a second “uncertainty principle.” It

is almost impossi-ble to prefigure the responses appropriate to a certain event in a social situation.

But a control-reading “profits are falling” does not indicate, with any de-gree of probability, the

response “raise prices,” let alone by how much; the control-reading “sales are falling” does not

indicate the response “cut prices,” and so on. The event itself may not even be meaningful. But

even if it is, it is by no means certain what it means.

ACTION POINT:

Review each of the performance measures you use to manage your organization.

Eliminate each of those measures that is not meaningful to the results of the organization.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

【原书原文】

Controls, Control, and Management

Controls and Control—The Characteristics of Controls—Controls Are Goal-Setting and Value-Setting—Controls

Needed for Measurable and for Nonmeasurable Events—The Specification for Controls—Economy—Meaning—

Controls Follow Strategy—Appropriateness—Congruence—Timeliness—Simplicity—Controls Must Be Operational—

The Ultimate Control of Organizations—Controls and the Spirit of an Organization

N THE DICTIONARY OF SOCIAL INSTITUTIONS, the word “controls” is not the plural of the word “control.” Not only do

more controls not necessarily give more con- trol, the two words, in the context of social institutions, have different

meanings alto- gether. The synonyms for controls are measurement and information. The synonym for control is

direction. Controls pertain to means, control to an end. Controls deal with facts, that is, with events of the past.

Control deals with expectations, that is, with the future. Controls are analytical, concerned with what was and is.

Control is normative and concerned with what ought to be.

We are rapidly acquiring great capacity to design controls in business and in other so- cial institutions, based on a

great improvement in techniques, especially in the application of logical and mathematical tools to events in a social

institution, and in the ability to process and analyze large masses of data very fast. What does this mean for control?

Spe- cifically, what are the requirements for these greatly improved controls to give better con- trol to management?

For, in the task of a manager, controls are purely a means to an end; the end is control.

Ordinary language and its use make abundantly clear that here is a problem. The man in a business who is charged

with producing the controls is the controller. But most, if not all executives, including most controllers themselves,

would consider it gross misuse and abuse of controllership were this controller to use his controls to exercise control

in the business. This, they would argue, would actually make the business be “out of control” altogether.

The reasons for this apparent paradox lie in the complexity both of human beings and of the social task.

If we deal with a human being in a social institution, controls must become personal motivation that leads to control.

Instead of a mechanical system, the control system in a human-social situation is a volitional system. That we know

very little about the will is not even the central point. A translation is required before the information yielded by the

controls can become grounds for action—the translation of one kind of information into another, which we call

perception.

In the social institution there is a second complexity, a second “uncertainty principle.” It is almost impossible to

prefigure the responses appropriate to a certain event in a social situation.

We can, and do, build controls into a machine which slow down the turning speed whenever it exceeds a certain figure.

And we can do this either by mechanical means or by instrumentation which shows a human operator what the turning

speed is, and which gives him the specific, unambiguous instruction to turn the speed down when the indicator

reaches a certain point. But a control-reading “profits are falling” does not indicate, with any degree of probability, the

response “raise prices,” let alone by how much; the control- reading “sales are falling” does not indicate the response

“cut prices,” and so on. There is not only a large number of other equally probable responses—so large that it is usually

not even possible to identify them in advance—there is also no indication in the event itself which of these responses

is even possible, let alone appropriate, not to mention its being right. The event itself may not even be meaningful. But

even if it is, it is by no means certain what it means. And the probability of its being meaningful is a much more

important datum than the event itself and one which is almost never to be discerned by analyzing the event.

Social situations require a decision based on assumptions—and essentially assump- tions not with respect to the

recorded event but to the future, that is, expectations which know no probability but can only be judged according to

plausibility. For there are no “facts” regarding the future in a social universe in which periodicity—at least on our minuscule time scale—cannot be assumed, must indeed be considered quite unlikely.

The Characteristics of Controls

There are three major characteristics of controls in business enterprise.

  1. Controls can be neither objective nor neutral. When we measure the rate of fall of a stone, we are totally outside the

event itself. By measuring we do not change the event; and measuring the event does not change us, the observers.

Measuring physical phenom- ena is both objective and neutral.

In a perceptual situation of complexity, that is, in any social situation of the kind we deal with in business enterprise,

the act of measurement is, however, neither objective nor neutral. It is subjective and of necessity biased. It changes

both the event and the ob- server. For it changes the perception of the observer—if it does not altogether create his

perception. Events in the social situation acquire value by the fact that they are being sin- gled out for the attention of

being measured. No matter how “scientific” we are, the fact that this or that set of phenomena is singled out for being

“controlled,” signals that it is being considered to be important.

Everybody who ever watched the introduction of a budget system has seen this hap- pen. For a long time—in some

companies forever—realizing the budget figures becomes more important than what the budget is supposed to

measure, namely economic perform- ance. Managers, upon first being exposed to

a budget system, often deliberately hold back sales and cut back profits rather than be guilty of “not making the

budget.” It takes years of experience and a very intelligent budget director to restore the balance. And there are any

number of otherwise perfectly normal research directors who act on the conviction that it is a greater crime to get

research results for less than the budgeted amount than not getting any research results at all while spending all the

“proper” budget money.

Controls in a social institution such as a business are goal-setting and value-setting. They are not “objective.” They are

of necessity moral. The only way to avoid this is to flood the executive with so many controls that the entire system

becomes meaningless, becomes mere “noise.”

From that point of view maybe the gross abuse of our new data-processing capacity, namely as a tool for grinding out

huge quantities of totally meaningless data—an abuse of which every early computer user is guilty—may be a blessing

after all.

But to render controls harmless by rendering them meaningless is hardly the right way to use our capacity to provide

controls. This must start out with the realization that con- trols create vision. They change both the events measured

and the observer. They endow

events not only with meaning but with value. And this means that the basic question is not “How do we control?” but

“What do we measure in our control system?”

  1. Controls need to focus on results. Business (and every other social institution) ex- ists to contribute to society,

economy, and individual. In consequence results in business exist only on the outside—in economy, in society, and with

the customer. It is the cus- tomer only who creates a “profit.” Everything inside a business—manufacturing, marketing, research, and so on—creates only costs, is only a “cost center.”

In other words, the managerial area is concerned with costs alone. But results are en- trepreneurial.

Yet we do not have adequate, let alone reliable, information regarding the “outside.” It is not only by far the hardest to

get—to the point where no organization for the acquisi- tion and collection of meaningful outside information could

really be set up—the job is much too big. Above all we still lack necessary entrepreneurial concepts. The job itself has

never been thought through—at least not so far. And the century of patient analysis of managerial, inside phenomena,

events and data, the century of patient, skillful work on the individual operations and tasks within the business, has no

counterpart with respect to the entrepreneurial job.

We can easily record and therefore quantify efficiency, that is, efforts. We have very few instruments to record and

quantify effects, that is, the outside. But even the most effi- cient buggywhip manufacturer would no longer be in business. It is of little value to have

the most efficient engineering department if it designs the wrong product. The Cuban sub- sidiaries of U.S. companies

were by far the best run and, apparently, the most profit- able—let alone the least “troublesome”—of all U.S.

operations in Latin America. This was, however, irrelevant to their expropriation. And it mattered little, I daresay, during

the period of IBM’s great expansion in the fifties and sixties how “efficient” its operations were; its basic

entrepreneurial idea was the right, the effective one.

The outside, the area of results, is much less accessible than the inside. The central problem of the executive in the

large organization is his—necessary—insulation from the outside. This applies to the president of the United States as

well as to the president of United States Steel. What today’s organization therefore needs are synthetic sense

organs for the outside. If modern controls are to make a contribution, it would be, above all, here.

  1. Controls are needed for measurable and non-measurable events. Business, like any other institution, has important

results that are incapable of being measured. Any experi- enced executive knows companies or industries which are

bound for extinction because

they cannot attract or hold able people. This, every experienced executive also knows, is a more important fact about

a company or an industry than last year’s profit statement. Any logical positivist who were to tell an executive that this

statement, being incapable of un- ambiguous definition, is a “non-statement” dealing with a “non-problem,” would be

quickly—and correctly—dismissed as an ass. Yet the statement cannot be defined clearly let alone “quantified.” It is

anything but “intangible”; it is very “tangible” indeed (as any- one ever having to do with such a business quickly finds

out). It is just non-measurable. And measurable results will not show up for a decade.

But business also has measurable and quantifiable results of true meaning and signifi- cance. These are all those that

have to do with past economic performance. For these can be expressed in terms of the very peculiar measurement of

the economic sphere, money.

This does not mean that these are “tangibles.” Indeed most of the things we can meas- ure by money are so totally

“intangible”—take depreciation for instance—that they outdo any Platonic Idea in that nothing corresponds to them in

any reality whatever. But they are measurable.

To this comes the fact that the measurable results are things that happened; they are in the past. There are no facts

about the future. To this comes, second, the fact that the measurable events are primarily inside events rather than

outside events. The important developments on the outside, the things which determine that the buggy-whip industry

disappears and that IBM becomes a big business—let alone that Cuban subsidiaries of American companies are

confiscated—are not measurable until it is too late to have con- trol.

A balance between the measurable and the non-measurable is therefore a central and constant problem of

management and a true decision area.

Measurements which do not spell out the assumptions with respect to the non- measurable statements that are being

made—at least as parameters or as restraints— misdirect therefore. They actually misinform. Yet the more we can

quantify the truly measurable areas, the greater the temptation to put all-out emphasis on those—the greater,

therefore, the danger that what looks like better controls will actually mean less control if not a business out of

control altogether.

Specifications for Controls

To give the manager control, controls must satisfy seven specifications:

  1. Control is a principle of economy. The less effort needed to gain control, the better the control design. The fewer

controls needed, the more effective they will be. Indeed, adding more controls does not give better control. All it does

is create confusion.

The first question the manager therefore needs to ask in designing or in using a system of controls is “What is the mini

mum information I need to know to have control?”

The answer may vary for different managers. The company’s treasurer needs only to know the total amount invested in

inventories and whether it is going up or down. The sales manager needs to know the half a dozen products and

product lines which together account for 70 percent of inventory, and those in considerable detail. But total inventory

amount is not of primary importance to him. And both the treasurer and the sales manager do not, as a rule, need

complete inventory figures except once or twice a year; a fairly small sample should give them all the information they

need in between. But the ware- house clerk needs daily figures—and in detail.

The capacity of the computer to spew out huge masses of data does not make for bet- ter controls. On the contrary,

what gives control is first the question “What is the smallest number of reports and statistics needed to understand a

phenomenon and to be able to anticipate it?” And then one asks, “And what is the minimum of data regarding this phenomenon that gives a reasonably reliable picture?”

  1. Controls must be meaningful. That means that the events to be measured must be significant either in themselves,

e.g., market standing, or they must be symptoms of at least potentially significant developments, e.g., a sudden sharp

rise in labor turnover or absenteeism.

Trivia should never be measured. One has control by controlling a few developments

which can have significant impact on performance and results. One loses control by trying to control the infinity of

events which are marginal to performance and results.

Controls should always be related to the key objectives and to the priorities within them, to “key activities” and to

“conscience areas” (see Chapter 42). Controls should, in other words, be based on a company’s definition of what our

business is, what it will be, and what it should be.

Controls Follow Strategy

Whatever is not essential to the attainment of a company’s objectives should be measured infrequently and only to

prevent deterioration. It should be strictly controlled by “excep- tion,” that is, a standard should be set, measurement

should be periodical and on a sample basis; and only significant shortfalls below the established standard should even

be re- ported, let alone paid attention to.

That we can quantify something is no reason for measuring it. The question is “Is this

what a manager should consider important?” “Is this what a manager’s attention should be focused on?” “Is this a true

statement of the basic realities of the enterprise?” “Is this the proper focus for control, that is, for effective direction

with maximum economy of ef- fort?”

If these questions are not being asked in designing controls, we will end up by making business essentially

uncontrolled—for then we will simply have no remedy except to pro- liferate control information to the point where it

does not register at all.

  1. Controls have to be appropriate to the character and nature of the phenomena measured. This may well be the most

important specification; yet it is least observed in the actual design of controls.

Because controls have such an impact it is not only important that we select the right ones. To enable controls to give

right vision and to become the ground for effective ac- tion, the measurement must also be appropriate. That is, it

must present the events meas- ured in structurally true form. Formal validity is not enough.

Formal complaints, that is, grievances, coming out of a work force are commonly re- ported as “five grievances per

thousand employees per month.” This is formally valid. But is it structurally valid? Or is it misdirection? The impression

this report conveys is, first, that grievances are distributed throughout the work force in a random manner. They follow,

the report seems to say, a U-shaped Gaussian distribution. And second—a conclu- sion from the first impression—they

are a minor problem, especially if we deal with five grievances per thousand employees per month. This, while formally

valid, completely misrepresents and misinforms, let alone misdirects.

Grievances are a social event. Physical nature knows no such phenomena. And social events are almost never

distributed in the “normal distribution” we find in the physical world. The normal distribution of social events is almost

always exponential—with the

hyperbola the typical curve. In other words, the great majority of departments in the plant, employing 95 percent of

the work force, normally does not have even a single grievance during one year. But in one department, employing

only a handful of men, we have a heavy incidence of grievances—

so that the “five per thousand” may well mean (and in the actual example from which I took these figures, did mean) a

major grievance per man per year. If this department is then the final assembly through which all the production has to

pass, and if the workers in this department go out on strike when their grievances are being neglected by a management which has been misled by its own controls, the impact can be shattering. It

bankrupted the company, which is no longer in existence.

Similarly, 90 percent of the volume of a business is usually represented by 2 to 5 per cent of the number of its

products. But 90 percent of the orders by number cover, typi- cally, only 4 or 5 percent of the volume—but account for

90 percent and more of the costs. A modern strategic bomber may have a million parts. But 90 percent of its cost is

represented by a very small number of parts, maybe fifty or so—and so is 90 percent of the upkeep it needs, though,

unfortunately, the 90 percent of the dollars and the 90 per- cent of the upkeep needs rarely comprise the same parts.

Practically all the innovations in a research laboratory, no matter how large, come out of the work of a very small

percentage of the research people. And invariably, 80 percent of a company’s distributors move, at best, 20 percent of

its output, while 10 percent or fewer of the distributors move two-thirds to three-quarters of total sales.

Most measurements of sales performance, whether of the entire sales force or of the individual salesman, report sales

in total dollars. But in many businesses this is an inap- propriate figure. The same dollar volume of sales may mean a

substantial profit, no profit at all, or a sizable loss—dependent on the product mix sold. An absolute sales figure

not related to product mix, therefore, gives no control whatever—neither to the individual salesman, nor to the sales

manager, nor to top management.

These are elementary things. Yet few managers seem to know them. The traditional information systems, especially

accounting, conceal appropriateness rather than highlight it. (In particular the allocation of overhead tends to obscure

the true distribution of eco- nomic and social phenomena.)

Without controls that bring out clearly what the real structure of events is, the manager not only lacks knowledge. He

will tend to do the wrong things. For all the weight of the daily work pushes him toward allocating energies and

resources in proportion to the num- ber of events. There is a constant drift toward putting energies and resources

where they can have the least results, that is, on the vast number of phenomena which, together, ac- count for

practically no effects.

  1. Measurements have to be congruent with the events measured. Alfred North Whitehead (1851-1947), the

distinguished logician and philosopher, used to warn against the “danger of the false concreteness.” A measurement

does not become more “accurate” by being worked out to the sixth decimal when the phenomenon measured is at

best capa- ble of being verified within a range of, say, 50 to 70 percent (and that, presumably, with an error of plus or

minus 20 percent). This is “false concreteness,” gross inaccuracy in reality, and misleading.

It is an important piece of information that this or that phenomenon cannot be meas- ured with precision but can be

described only within a range or as a magnitude. To say “we have 26 percent of the market” sounds reassuringly

precise. But it is usually so inac- curate a statement as to be virtually meaningless. What it really means, as a rule, is

“we are not the dominant factor in the market, but we are not marginal either.” And even then the statement is no more

reliable than the definition of the market which underlies it.

It is up to the manager to think through what kind of measurement is congruent to the phenomenon it is meant to

measure. He has to know when “approximate” is more accu- rate than a firmlooking figure worked out in great detai1. He has to know when a range is more accurate than even an approximate

single figure. He has to know that “larger” and “smaller,” “earlier” and “later,” “up” and “down” are quantitative terms

and often more accurate, indeed more rigorous, than any specific figures or range of figures.

  1. Controls have to be timely. The time dimension of controls is very similar to their congruence. Again frequent

measurements and very rapid “reporting back” do not neces- sarily give better control. Indeed they may frustrate

control. The time dimension of con- trols has to correspond to the time span of the event measured.

It has lately become fashionable to talk of “real time” controls, that is, of controls that inform instantaneously and

continuously. There are events where “real time” controls are highly desirable. If a batch of antibiotics in the

fermentation tank spoils as soon as tem- perature or pressure deviate from a very narrow range for more than a

moment or two, “real time” monitoring on a continuous basis is obviously needed. But few events need such controls.

And most cannot be controlled at all by them. “Real time” is the wrong time span for real control.

Children planting a garden are so impatient, it is said, that they tend to pull out the radishes as soon as their leaves

show, to see whether the root is forming. This is “real time” control—misapplied.

When a new product is being first introduced, the product manager may want and need daily reports from the test

markets, and as close to “real time” as possible. Six months later, when he has worked out his promotion and selling

strategy, daily reports in “real time” can only lead him into “pulling up the radish to see whether the root is form-

ing.” He then needs to think through at what periods of time and in what areas he has to attain what results to be able

to achieve his objectives. And then he has to pay the greatest attention to the measurement of results at their crucial

moments in time. If he, however, worries about “real time” daily measurements, he is almost bound to confuse himself

and his associates and to muddle even the best strategy. Similarly, the attempt to measure re- search progress all the

time is likely to confound research results. The proper time span for research is a fairly long one. Once every two or

three years research progress and re- search results should be rigorously appraised. In between an experienced

manager keeps in touch. He watches for any indication of major unexpected trouble, and, even more, for any sign of

unexpected breakthroughs. But to monitor research in “real time”—as some research labs have been trying to do—is

pulling up the radishes.

However, there is also the opposite danger—that of not measuring often enough. It is particularly great with

developments that (a) take a fairly long time to have results, and

  1. have to come together at a point in the future to produce the desired end result.
  1. Controls need to be simple. Every major New York commercial bank worked in the sixties on developing internal

controls, especially of costs and of allocation of efforts. Everyone spent a great deal of time and money on the task

and came up with voluminous control manuals. In only one of the banks are the manuals being used, to the best of my

knowledge. When the executive in that bank was asked how he explained this, he did not (as his interviewer expected

him to) credit a massive training program or talk about his “philosophy.” He said instead, “I have two teen-age

daughters. They know nothing about banking and are not terribly good at figures. But they are bright. Whenever I had

worked out an approach to controlling an activity, I took my intended procedure home in draft form and asked my girls

to let me explain it to them. And only when I had it so simple that they could explain back to me what the procedure

intended to accomplish and how, did I go ahead. Only then was it simple enough.”

Complicated controls do not work. They confuse. They misdirect from what is to be controlled toward attention on the

mechanics and methodology of the control. But if the user has to know how the control works before he can apply it,

he has no control at all. And if he has to sit down and figure out what a measurement means, he has no control either.

Indeed, the bank executive’s method is a pretty good one. Training sessions in using a new control rarely accomplish

much. Ask the intended user to explain its purpose and its use. And when he stumbles over complexities, ambiguities,

or subtleties, redesign for simplicity.

Finally, controls must be operational. They must be focused on action. Action rather than information is their purpose.

The action may be only study and analysis. In other words, a measurement may say, “What goes on we don’t

understand; but something

goes on that needs to be understood.” But it should never just say, “Here is something you might find interesting.”

This then means that controls—whether reports, studies, or figures—must always reach the person who is capable of

taking controlling action. Whether they should reach anyone else—and especially someone higher up—is debatable.

But their prime addressee is the manager or professional who can take action by virtue of his position in the flow of

work and in the decision structure. And this further means that the measurement must be in a form that is suitable for

the recipient and tailored to his needs.

Workers and first-line supervisors should, as said earlier (Chapter 18) receive meas- urements and control information

that enable them to direct their own immediate efforts toward results they can control. Instead, typically, the first-line

supervisor receives each month a statement of the quality control results for the entire plant—and the worker

re- ceives nothing.

And top management usually receives the information and measurements operating middle managers need and can

use, and little or nothing of pertinence to their own top- management job.

The reason for this is largely a confusion between control as domination of others and control as rational behavior.

Unless controls are means toward the latter, and this means toward self-control, they lead to wrong action. They are

“mis-control.”

The Ultimate Control of Organizations

There is one more important thing to be said. There is a fundamental, incurable, basic limitation to controls in a social

institution. This lies in the fact that a social institution is both a true entity and a fiction. As an entity it has purposes of

its own, a performance of its own, results of its own—and survival and death of its own. These are the areas of which

we have been speaking so far. But a social institution is comprised of persons, each with his own purpose, his own

ambitions, his own ideas, his own needs. No matter how authoritarian the institution, it has to satisfy the ambitions and

needs of its members, and do so in their capacity as individuals but through institutional rewards and punishments,

incentives, and deterrents. The expression of this may be quantifiable—such as a raise in salary. But the system itself

is not quantitative in character and cannot be quantified.

Yet here is the real control of the institution, that is, the ground of behavior and the cause of action. People act as they

are being rewarded or punished. For this, to them, rightly (as said earlier in Chapter 36), is the true expression of the

values of the institution and of its true, as against its professed, purpose and role.

A system of controls which is not in conformity with this true, this only effective, this

ultimate control of the organization which lies in its people decisions will therefore at best be ineffectual. At worst it

will cause never-ending conflict and will push the organization out of control.

In designing controls for an organization one has to understand and analyze the actual control of the business, its

people decisions. Otherwise one designs a system of controls

which does not lead to control. One has to realize that even the most powerful “instrument board” complete with

computers, operations research, and simulation, is secondary to the invisible, qualitative control of any human

organization, its systems of rewards and pun- ishments, of values and taboos.

23 SEPTEMBER

Controls, Control, and Management

The probability of an event’s being meaningful

is a much more important datum than the event itself.

We are rapidly acquiring great capacity to design controls in business

and in other social institutions, based on a great improvement in techniques,

especially the ability to process and analyze large masses of data very fast.

What does this mean for “control”? Especially, what are the requirements for

these greatly improved controls to give better control to management? For, in

the task of a manager, controls are purely a means to an end; the end is

control. If we deal with a human being in a social insti-tution, controls must

become personal motivation that leads to control. A translation is required

before the information yielded by the controls can become grounds for action

—the translation of one kind of information into another, which we call

perception. In the social institution there is a second complexity, a second

“uncertainty principle.” It is almost impossi-ble to prefigure the responses

appropriate to a certain event in a social situ-

ation.

But a control-reading “profits are falling” does not indicate, with any

de-gree of probability, the response “raise prices,” let alone by how much;

the control-reading “sales are falling” does not indicate the response “cut

prices,” and so on. The event itself may not even be meaningful. But even

if it is, it is by no means certain what it means.

ACTION POINT:

Review each of the performance measures you use to

manage your organization. Eliminate each of those measures that is not

meaningful to the results of the organization.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

抽烟的人不配有老婆?

KEY： 考核，肯定是不客观的，也不是中立的。更神奇的是，他不但影响被考核的对象，也影响

考核者。

昨天的文字《你为什么找不到男朋友》中，我建议女生消除那些没有意义的考核项，来增大遇见男朋

友的概率。我举例了一些”没有意义的考核项”，比如是否985毕业，是否抽烟，身高，地域等等等等。

1

2

考核，肯定是不客观的，也不是中立的。更神奇的是，他不但影响被考核的对象，也影响考核者。

阿斯顿发斯蒂芬

很多同学对我举的这些例子很有意见，有同学说，男生1米6，女生1米9，肯定不行呀；有的同学说，

女生985，男生不是985，两个人完全不是一个阶层，肯定也过不到一起呀；他认为“高学历人毕业以

后难道学到的仅仅是知识吗？她身边的老师同学以及同事给她带来的文化熏陶，她们之间谈论的话

题，都是低学历人无法企及的。所以高学历人和低学历人大多数是无法长时间相处的，何谈婚姻？”

“难道让芸芸单身高学历女性朋友在茫茫的单身低学历男性朋友中寻找适合自己的婚姻？岂不荒

谬？”；

有同学说“抽烟真的会对我的生活有影响，而且对全家人的健康都有影响，所以抽烟一定会被列为排除

标准！”。更有一个同学说“抽烟的人不配有老婆！”

看到大家讨论消除排他项，我觉得，至少大家认可了“应该消除那些没有意义的考核项”，只是对“无意

义的考核项”，大家有不同的看法，这个是非常正常的。

对于有的人来说，抽烟就是很重要的，985就是很重要的，身高就是很重要的，只要你经过思考后还认

为这是很重要的，那么它就是很重要的，这个没有对错，不用去说服别人，也不用被别人说服。

毕竟，你的选择在决定这你的结果，而你的结果也在影响着你的改变。

因为，你想要的，你一定会得到，而你只能得到你想要的。比如，你认为抽烟这件事很重要，那么，

遇到抽烟的你就会绕开，不管你多喜欢这个人，也不管这个人多喜欢你；也不在意这个人对你多好，

也不在意这个人在世俗意义上有多么地成功。

哪怕他愿意为你戒烟。

如果你觉得985很重要，那么，你就会把眼光放在985上，那么那是个30岁的职场精英也和你无关，

哪怕他对你体贴入微，也只是午后甜点。哪怕他帅的掉渣，也要忍痛割爱。

如果你觉得身高很重要，那么，哪怕他才华横溢，名校大厂，年入百万，幽默风趣，也只好遗憾说再

见了。

事实就是这样，你的选择，只要你坚持，你一定会得到。你会得到一个不抽烟的男人，你会得到985制

造出来的一个男人，你会得到一个身材高大的男人。

而你，也会被你的选择所改变。

今天在群里讨论这个话题时，作为直男的我，还是说了自己注定被骂的观点：找对象，不管是找男朋

友还是女朋友，只有一个条件，诚实正直，其他的都可以忽略。

是呀，他抽烟，当然可以戒烟了，身边太多朋友在某个特定时刻戒烟了，比如孩子出生时，或者结婚

时，或者某个时刻。

他的学历不佳，如果工作或者生活需要，他可以去学习呀。他的身高是不高，不过，他诙谐、幽默，

可以给大家带来欢乐，大家都喜欢他呀。

不管他的过去如何，你选择的是他的未来。而未来，并不（只）是由他的过去决定，还有你们共同的

努力决定。你可以用你认为重要的任何选项来过滤，而结果，你一定会得到。

只要你确定这是你想要的。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

24 SEPTEMBER

Controls: Neither Objective nor Neutral

Neutral：

not supporting or helping either side in a disagreement, competition, etc.

中立的；持平的；无倾向性的

The act of measurement changes both the event and the observer.

In any social situation of the kind we deal with in enterprise, the act of measurement is neither

objective nor neutral.

It is subjective and of necessity biased.

biased：

(toward(s)/against/in favour of sb/sth) having a tendency to show favour towards or against one group of people or one

opinion for personal reasons; making unfair judgements

of necessity：必然地；不可避免地

有偏见的；倾向性的；片面的

It changes both the event and the observer.

Events in the social situation acquire value by the fact that they are being singled out for the

attention of being measured.

The fact that this or that set of phenomena is singled out for being “controlled” signals that it is

considered to be important.

Controls in a social institution such as a business are goal-setting and value-setting.

They are not “objective.” They are of necessity moral.

Controls create vision.

They change both the events measured and the observer.

They endow events not only with meaning but with value.

And this means that the basic question is not “How do we control?” but “What do we measure in

our control system?”

ACTION POINT:

Remember, “What you measure is what you get.”

Ensure that every measure of performance is pertinent to the achievement of a goal or value of

your organization.

Otherwise, you risk misdirecting your organization.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

24 SEPTEMBER

Controls: Neither Objective nor Neutral

The act of measurement changes both the event and the observer.

In any social situation of the kind we deal with in enterprise, the act of

measurement is neither objective nor neutral. It is subjective and of ne-cessity

biased. It changes both the event and the observer. Events in the so-cial situation

acquire value by the fact that they are being singled out for the attention of being

measured. The fact that this or that set of phenomena is singled out for being

“controlled” signals that it is considered to be impor-tant. Controls in a social

institution such as a business are goal-setting and value-setting. They are not

“objective.” They are of necessity moral. Con-trols create vision. They change

both the events measured and the ob-server. They endow events not only with

meaning but with value. And this means that the basic question is not “How do

we control?” but “What do we

measure in our control system?”

ACTION POINT:

Remember, “What you measure is what you get.” Ensure

that every measure of performance is pertinent to the achievement of

Agoal or value of your organization. Otherwise, you risk misdirecting your

organi-zation.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

可怜的瑛姑

金庸笔下的有很神的女生，叫做瑛姑。

她的第一个老公是段智兴，是大理的在任皇帝。段智兴在江湖上也很有地位，江湖上人称南帝，是第

一次华山论剑的五绝之一。以一阳指扬名天下。

她第二个男人是老顽童，老顽童是第一次华山论剑的五绝之首，中神通王重阳的师弟，同时也是第三

次华山论剑的五绝之首。武功堪称天下第一。

看起来这个女人来历非常不一般，她后来流落江湖，“隐居”在一个地方。已经退位为僧的段智兴（这

时已经是一灯大师）还是安排了一些人为她提供基本的生活服务。

不过，这时的瑛姑是有任务的，她要去救她的情郎，也就是老顽童。

听说，老顽童被黄药师关在了桃花岛，而且没有去搭救，瑛姑觉得这是自己的责任，就决定去救。

第一次去救时，被困在了桃花岛的阴阳五行阵里，差点饿死了。回来后，瑛姑就开始学习术数，以求

攻破桃花岛的阵法，救出自己的情郎黄药师。

在长达十几年的学习中，瑛姑非常努力，每天都在做题，演算。每天都在进步，中间也想着再去桃花

岛试试。想想还是算了：继续学习吧。

瑛姑觉得自己学的不错，某一天就自称为神算子了。觉得自己可以去桃花岛了。想着可以救出自己心

爱的老顽童，做梦都能笑醒了。

要不是遇到一个叫做黄蓉的女孩的话。黄蓉是黄药师的女儿，跟着黄药师学了几年术数，瑛姑发现黄

蓉的学识超过自己百倍！自己去救老顽童肯定没戏。

正在瑛姑焦虑中，黄蓉告诉她老顽童早就离开了桃花岛。瑛姑顿时怂了一口气：还好还好，自己不用

去救情郎了。

于是，瑛姑开始了下半生的日子，就是追着老顽童跑。

瑛姑打听到老顽童要去华山，就去华山找老顽童。没成想，老顽童看到瑛姑就吓跑了，瑛姑在后面

追，老顽童在前面跑。

以瑛姑的武功，怎么能追上老顽童？不过老顽童还是被吓尿了。据说屎尿齐流。

瑛姑并没有放手，继续四处打听，只要有老顽童的消息就追过去，却重来也没追到。

就这样，几十年过去了，瑛姑始终没有追到老顽童，哪怕说一句话的机会都没与。瑛姑终于明白老顽

童其实就是不想见自己。

后来，听说老顽童在百花谷里常驻了，瑛姑悄悄来到百花谷附近一个叫做黑龙潭的地方，也住了下

来，开始了自己的晚年生活。

有一天，黑龙潭来了一个年轻人，带着一个小姑娘。年轻人想要自己养的一对九尾灵狐。这么多年

来，在一灯和瑛姑的“照应”下，没有什么人吃饱了撑的去惹她。而且，瑛姑每天也在勤练武功，慢慢

地，瑛姑觉得自己的武功也不错了，甚至觉得很厉害了，最多也就打不过一灯、老顽童等几个人，自

己应该算得上是一流的武林高手了。只是一直没有机会施展。

瑛姑看到年轻人没有礼貌，就下了杀招：寒阴箭，想把这个年轻人直接杀死得了。没想到，中了寒阴

箭的年轻人，居然行动如常。

这时，瑛姑才知道，自己的武功和真正江湖上的武功差的太远了。

瑛姑是一个很普通的女子，容貌普通，天赋普通，只是因为遇到了一灯，然后又遇到了老顽童才让她

显得如此不同。

这样的女生，本来应该没有什么事情，可是她又偏偏一辈子都有事情要做。先是要救老顽童，接着就

是去追老顽童。这个本来不该进入江湖的女子，就这样进入了江湖。也因为对江湖的不了解，闹了一

辈子的笑话。

幸运的是，老年后的她，最终还是和老顽童做了邻居，不用再去追来追去的了。这时的她已经头发花

白了，终于不用穿江湖人的马甲了。做了一个琐琐碎碎的小女人。也不用怕再闹什么笑话了。

只需要给老顽童圆谎就好了：“太阳自然从西边出来呀，哪见过太阳从东边出来呀……”

桃花岛

杨过

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

25 SEPTEMBER

Controls Should Focus on Results

What today’s organization needs are synthetic sense organs for the outside.

synthetic：

语言

语言

( linguistics

) ( also ag·glu·tin·ative ) ( of languages

separate words to show the functions of words in a sentence

sense：

综合（型）的

) using changes to the ends of words rather than

[ C ] one of the five powers (sight, hearing, smell, taste and touch) that your body uses to get information about the world

around you

organ：

感觉官能（即视、听、嗅、味、触五觉）

a part of the body that has a particular purpose, such as the heart or the brain; part of a plant with a particular purpose

体或动植物的）器官

Every social institution exists to contribute to society, economy, and individual.

institution：

模大的）机构

[ C ] a large important organization that has a particular purpose, for example, a university or bank

（人

（大学、银行等规

In consequence results exist only on the outside—in economy, in society, and with the customer.

in consequence：因此；结果

It is the customer only who creates a profit.

Everything inside a business creates only costs, is only a “cost center.”

But results are entrepreneurial.

entrepreneurial：adj. 企业家的，创业者的；中间商的

Yet we do not have adequate, let alone reliable, information regarding the “outside.”

adequate：

足够的；合格

(for sth) | ~ (to do sth) enough in quantity, or good enough in quality, for a particular purpose or need

的；合乎需要的

let alone：更不必说；听任；不打扰

regarding：

concerning sb/sth; about sb/sth

关于；至于

The century of patient analysis of managerial, inside phenomena, events and data, the century

of patient, skillful work on the individual operations and tasks within the business, has no

counterpart with respect to the entrepreneurial job.

century：

年；百年

patient：

有耐心的；

a period of 100 years 100

能忍耐的

(with sb/sth) able to wait for a long time or accept annoying behaviour or difficulties without becoming angry

managerial：

phenomena：n. 现象（phenomenon 的复数 ）

counterpart：

[ usually before noun ] connected with the work of a manager

经理的；管理的

a person or thing that has the same position or function as sb/sth else in a different place or situation

职位（或作

用）相当的人；对应的事物

respect：[ U sing. ] ~ (for sb/sth) a feeling of admiration for sb/sth because of their good qualities or achievements 尊敬；敬意；尊

重

entrepreneurial job：

We can easily record and therefore quantify efficiency, that is, efforts.

quantify：

以数量表述；量化

efficiency：

效率；效能；功效

efforts：

努力

[ VN ] to describe or express sth as an amount or a number

[ U ] the quality of doing sth well with no waste of time or money

N-VAR If you make an effort to do something, you try very hard to do it.

It is of little value to have the most efficient engineering department if it designs the wrong

product.

And it mattered little, I dare say, during the period of IBM’s great expansion in the fifties and sixties

how “efficient” its operations were; its basic entrepreneurial idea was the right, the effective one.

entrepreneurial：adj. 企业家的，创业者的；中间商的

The outside, the area of results, is much less accessible than the inside.

accessible：

可到达的；可接近的；可进入的；可使用的；可见到的

that can be reached, entered, used, seen, etc.

The central problem of executives in the large organization is their insulation from the outside.

insulation：

[ U ] the act of protecting sth with a material that prevents heat, sound, electricity, etc. from passing through; the

materials used for this

隔热；隔音；绝缘；隔热（或隔音、绝缘）材料

What today’s organization therefore needs are synthetic sense organs for the outside.

synthetic sense organs：综合性的感觉器官

If modern controls are to make a contribution, it would be, above all, here.

contribution：

贡献；促成作用

[ C usually sing. ] an action or a service that helps to cause or increase sth

ACTION POINT:

Develop a systematic method of collecting critical information on the environment.

The information should include knowledge of customer satisfaction, noncustomer buying

habits, technological developments, competitors, and relevant government policies.

relevant：

紧密相关的；切题的

closely connected with the subject you are discussing or the situation you are thinking about

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

25 SEPTEMBER

Controls Should Focus on Results

What today’s organization needs are synthetic sense organs for the outside.

Every social institution exists to contribute to society, economy, and in-

dividual. In consequence results exist only on the outside—in econ-omy, in

society, and with the customer. It is the customer only who creates a profit.

Everything inside a business creates only costs, is only a “cost cen-ter.” But

results are entrepreneurial. Yet we do not have adequate, let alone reliable,

information regarding the “outside.” The century of patient analy-sis of

managerial, inside phenomena, events and data, the century of pa-tient,

skillful work on the individual operations and tasks within the business, has

no counterpart with respect to the entrepreneurial job. We can easily record

and therefore quantify efficiency, that is, efforts. It is of lit-tle value to have

the most efficient engineering department if it designs the wrong product.

And it mattered little, I daresay, during the period of IBM’s great expansion

in the fifties and sixties how “efficient” its operations were;

its basic entrepreneurial idea was the right, the effective one.

The outside, the area of results, is much less accessible than the inside.

The central problem of executives in the large organization is their insula-

tion from the outside. What today’s organization therefore needs are syn-

thetic sense organs for the outside. If modern controls are to make

Acontribution, it would be, above all, here.

ACTION POINT:

Develop a systematic method of collecting critical infor-

mation on the environment. The information should include knowledge of

customer satisfaction, noncustomer buying habits, technological devel-

opments, competitors, and relevant government policies.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

金庸笔下的顶级高手很少有被打死的。我梳理了一下，到了顶级高手的位置，还被打死的好像只有东

方不败和洪安通两人。其中，东方不败顶级高手的位置是毋庸置疑的。

那么，东方不败是怎么死的呢？是被4个人打死了，这四个人是令狐冲、任我行、向问天和任盈盈。

令狐冲身兼独孤九剑和吸星大法，任我行本来就是一流高手，向问天也是二流里顶尖的人物，任盈盈

应该算黄蓉一流的人物。在这些人的围攻下，东方不败仍然没有败。仍然好整以暇地唠嗑。

在当时对阵的双方，东方一方有东方不败，杨莲亭。任我行一方有任我行、向问天，任盈盈、令狐

冲。其实，还有一个人，大家都忽略了，就是熊百童。

熊百童和东方不败是过命的交情。只是被杨莲亭诬陷。但他的心还是在东方不败那边的。

也就是说，现场的格局是：东方不败，杨莲亭，熊百童 VS 任我行、向问天、令狐冲、任盈盈。

东方不败是超一流的，事实证明，东方不败打败任我行、令狐冲和向问天是没问题的。熊百童打败任

盈盈也是没问题的。杨莲亭呆着就好了。

可惜，东方不败在战斗开始前做了一个错误的决定：一针杀死了熊百童。

熊百童是东方不败的人，要少熊百童，并不需要东方不败动手，杨莲亭就够了。可是，在面临前所未

有的敌人面前，东方不败选择了杀死熊百童，而不是联合熊百童。

最后，东方不败死了，仅仅因为任盈盈攻击杨莲亭影响了东方不败的判断。如果熊百童没死的话，完

全可以保护杨莲亭不被任盈盈攻击。可惜了。

再有就是洪安通。当洪安通决定一战时。其实局面是非常好的，自己这面有自己，还有胖头陀、许雪

亭，无根道人等。而地方只有韦小宝，和夫人苏荃。不过，苏荃怀孕的问题，让他实在气不过。

气不过也很正常，男人么。那就杀死给自己带绿帽子的得了。也就是韦小宝。那是的洪安通杀死韦小

宝还是很容易的，不过，他并没有这么做，而是突然向胖头陀、许雪亭，无根道人等动手，也就是向

自己人动手。

最后的结果大家都知道了，洪安通和胖头陀、许雪亭，无根道人等人拼的精疲力尽，最后被韦小宝杀

死。

我发现，这些死于意外的绝顶高手都有一个特点，就是发生问题是，先向自己人动手，殊不知，自己

人是最好消灭的，而且几乎是不会反抗的。而且是可以联合的。

如果东方不败联合了熊百童，如果洪安通联合了胖头陀、许雪亭，无根道人，我想任我行、令狐冲等

人，韦小宝等人，估计早就坟头高耸了。

遗憾。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

26 SEPTEMBER

Controls for Nonmeasurable Events

A balance between the measurable and the nonmeasurable is a central and constant problem of

management.

Business, like any other institution, has important results that are incapable of being measured.

Any experienced executive knows companies or industries that are bound for extinction because

they cannot attract or hold able people.

This, every experienced executive also knows, is a more important fact about a company or an

industry than last year’s profit statement.

Yet the statement cannot be defined clearly let alone “quantified.” It is anything but “intangible”; it

is very “tangible” indeed.

It is just nonmeasurable.

And measurable results will not show up for a decade.

A balance between the measurable and the nonmeasurable is therefore a central and constant

problem of management and a true decision area.

Measurements that do not spell out the assumptions with respect to the nonmeasurable

statements that are being made—misdirect, therefore.

They actually misinform.

Yet the more we can quantify the truly measurable areas, the greater the temptation to put all-out

emphasis on those—the greater, therefore, the danger that what looks like better controls will

actually mean less control if not a business out of control altogether.

ACTION POINT:

List both nonmeasurable and measurable variables that are important to the achievement of the

goals of your organization.

Develop quantitative assessments for those variables that can be so measured and qualitative

assessments for those critical variables that are qualitative.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

26 SEPTEMBER

Controls for Nonmeasurable Events

A balance between the measurable and the nonmeasurable is a central

and constant problem of management.

Business, like any other institution, has important results that are

inca-pable of being measured. Any experienced executive knows compa-

nies or industries that are bound for extinction because they cannot attract

or hold able people. This, every experienced executive also knows, is

Amore important fact about a company or an industry than last year’s profit

statement. Yet the statement cannot be defined clearly let alone “quanti-

fied.” It is anything but “intangible”; it is very “tangible” indeed. It is just

nonmeasurable. And measurable results will not show up for a decade.

A balance between the measurable and the nonmeasurable is therefore

Acentral and constant problem of management and a true decision area.

Measurements that do not spell out the assumptions with respect to the

nonmeasurable statements that are being made—misdirect, therefore. They

actually misinform. Yet the more we can quantify the truly measura-ble areas,

the greater the temptation to put all-out emphasis on those—the greater,

therefore, the danger that what looks like better controls will actu-ally mean

less control if not a business out of control altogether.

ACTION POINT:

List both nonmeasurable and measurable variables that are

important to the achievement of the goals of your organization. De-velop

quantitative assessments for those variables that can be so measured and

qualitative assessments for those critical variables that are qualitative.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

张无忌应该处罚范瑶么？

范瑶是明教的高管，明教光明右使，世称范右使。范瑶又是一个帅哥，和杨逍并称逍遥二仙：武功、

才华、地位都是一流的。

那一年，范瑶爱上了同事“紫衫龙王”黛绮丝，虽然明教没有规定同事不能恋爱，可是黛绮丝自己不喜

欢他。虽然他高富帅。

后来，老大阳顶天消失了，没几天自己喜欢的女人黛绮丝也消失了。明教开始内乱了起来，范瑶觉得

老大一定还活着，就独自离开光明顶，去找老大。

在找老大的过程中，范瑶发现自己兄弟金毛狮王谢逊的师父成昆居然要毁掉明教。这是一个很奇怪的

事情。而且，为了毁掉明教，成昆居然和玄冥二老一起归附了汝阳王，为元政府出力。

范瑶觉得这中间肯定有巨大的秘密，为了探听这个秘密，范瑶伪装后进入汝阳王府。作为帅哥的范

瑶，由于容貌出众 ，颇有一些名气，为了掩饰自己的容貌，干脆自毁容貌。这样就没人认识自己了，

更不用说成昆他们了。

进入汝阳王府后，为了表示自己和汝阳王府是一条心，和明教势不两立，范瑶亲手杀死了三位明教的

香主。香主在明教属于中层干部。

明教有一条明文规定：任何情况下不得伤害本教兄弟。而范瑶不但伤害了本教兄弟，而且杀死了本教

兄弟，不但杀死了，还杀死了三个。

这是非常严重的事情。

当范瑶见到新教主张无忌后，就向张无忌汇报了这个事情，请求教主的原宥。张无忌综合考虑后，决

定原谅范瑶，同时决定重申不得伤害本教兄弟的原则。

范瑶感觉到教主的不满，随即拿出匕首剁下了自己的一根手指头。张无忌一看，赶忙发誓，并要范瑶

发誓不再伤害自己。并表示原谅范瑶。

也就是说，张无忌在本来计划原谅范瑶的时候，被迫原谅了范瑶。其主要原因是范遥对明教有巨大贡

献，而且违反教规（杀死三名香主）也是为了更好地完成任务。

那么张无忌应该原谅范瑶么？张无忌这时应该处罚范瑶么？

对于管理者来说，其所拥有的管理手段无外乎赏罚。对优秀的、好的、积极的进行赏，对错误的，不

好的，消极的进行罚。通过赏罚来维持组织的正常运转。

在一个组织里，不管这个组织是独裁的还是民主的，其内部的每一个人都有自己的诉求，就像加入少

林的寿南山等。组织需要满足每一个人的诉求。当然，组织本身也有诉求，组织的存在是为了满足自

己的诉求。为了满足组织的诉求，管理者需要满足组织中每一个人的诉求：安全诉求，生活保障诉

求，精神诉求等等。为了满足组织的诉求，管理者又需要对组织内每一个成员进行赏罚，而赏罚的标

准就是组织的价值观，组织的目标。

因为，组织内的每一个人都是根据自己被赏、罚而做事的，被赏了，就会强化，被罚了，就会绕开。

那么张无忌应该处罚范瑶么？

范瑶是明教的高管，而且是明教教义的忠实信仰者。他的诉求就是明教的存在，以及明教的兴旺。而

这个诉求和明教本身的诉求很接近。

范瑶犯了错误，而且是重罪。不过，如果张无忌处罚这个罪，就意味着对范遥做的那些事的不认可，

也就意味着，以后再有范遥这样的人，再遇到范遥这样的事，他们不会这么做了。而是明哲保身。

而这，并不符合明教的利益和目标。

所以，虽然张无忌被迫免除了对范遥的处罚，这个决定确实非常正确的。因为它带来的益处是坏处

的。

当然，事后对教规的重申也是必要的。毕竟，这是一个教派之所以可以存在的基础。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

27 SEPTEMBER

The Ultimate Control of Organizations

Ultimate：

最后的；最终的；终极的

happening at the end of a long process

People act as they are being rewarded or punished.

punished：

There is a fundamental, incurable, basic limitation to controls in a social institution.

incurable：

不能治愈

fundamental：

十分重大的；根本的

that cannot be cured

serious and very important; affecting the most central and important parts of sth

A social institution is comprised of persons, each with his own purpose, his own ambitions, his

own ideas, his own needs.

comprised：

V-T If you say that something comprises or is comprised of a number of things or people, you mean it has them as

its parts or members.

包含; 由…组成

No matter how authoritarian the institution, it has to satisfy the ambitions and needs of its

members, and do so in their capacity as individuals through institutional rewards and punishments,

incentives, and deterrents.

authoritarian：

believing that people should obey authority and rules, even when these are unfair, and even if it means that they

lose their personal freedom

incentives：

deterrents：

威权主义的；专制的

N-VAR If something is an incentive to do something, it encourages you to do it.

鼓励

N-COUNT A deterrent is something that prevents people from doing something by making them afraid of what will

happen to them if they do it.

威慑物

The expression of this may be quantifiable—such as a raise in salary.

But the system itself is not quantitative in character and cannot be quantified.

quantitative：

数量的；量化的；定量性的

connected with the amount or number of sth rather than with how good it is

Yet here is the real control of the institution.

People act as they are being rewarded or punished.

For this, to them, rightly, is the true expression of the values of the institution and of its true, as

against its professed, purpose and role.

professed：

公开表明的

used to describe a belief or a position that sb has publicly made known

A system of controls that is not in conformity with this ultimate control of the organization, which

lies in its people decisions, will therefore at best be ineffectual.

At worst it will cause never-ending conflict and will push the organization out of control.

In designing controls for an organization, one has to understand and analyze the actual control of

the business, its people decisions.

One has to realize that even the most powerful “instrument board” complete with computers is

secondary to the invisible, qualitative control of any human organization, its systems of rewards

and punishments, of values and taboos.

ACTION POINT:

Specify the system of rewards and punishments in your organization, including the procedure used

for making promotion decisions.

Evaluate the performance measures in place in your organization.

Make sure that good performance on the performance measures leads to rewards, promotions,

and punishments.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

27 SEPTEMBER

The Ultimate Control of Organizations

People act as they are being rewarded or punished.

There is a fundamental, incurable, basic limitation to controls in a so-cial

institution. A social institution is comprised of persons, each with his own

purpose, his own ambitions, his own ideas, his own needs. No mat-

ter how authoritarian the institution, it has to satisfy the ambitions and

needs of its members, and do so in their capacity as individuals through

in-stitutional rewards and punishments, incentives, and deterrents. The

ex-pression of this may be quantifiable—such as a raise in salary. But the

system itself is not quantitative in character and cannot be quantified.

Yet here is the real control of the institution. People act as they are being

rewarded or punished. For this, to them, rightly, is the true expression of the

values of the institution and of its true, as against its professed, purpose and

role. A system of controls that is not in conformity with this ultimate control

of the organization, which lies in its people decisions, will therefore at best be

ineffectual. At worst it will cause never-ending conflict and will push the

organization out of control. In designing controls for an organiza-tion, one

has to understand and analyze the actual control of the business, its people

decisions. One has to realize that even the most powerful “in-strument board”

complete with computers is secondary to the invisible, qualitative control of

any human organization, its systems of rewards and punishments, of values

and taboos.

ACTION POINT:

Specify the system of rewards and punishments in your

organization, including the procedure used for making promotion deci-

sions. Evaluate the performance measures in place in your organization.

Make sure that good performance on the performance measures leads to

rewards, promotions, and punishments.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

黄蓉：我决定陪靖哥哥去死

蒙古军队已经围了襄阳一年多了，眼看着襄阳要守不住了。这天，黄蓉把耶律齐，大小武，郭芙，郭

襄，郭破虏还有郭芙的孩子们都叫到屋里，大家商量逃离的事情。

几十年来，郭靖、黄蓉很少离开襄阳，对江湖也不大了解了，不过，以他们的武功还有声望，可以去

的地方还是挺多的。

“桃花岛吧，桃花岛易守难攻，蒙古军队也不一定会去攻打”

“过儿的古墓也可以去，那里很大，而且本来就是军事要塞，可以做后续力量的储备”

“去西边吧，西边地势险要，有很多山，也便于积蓄力量，至少可以躲开蒙古兵的追击”

“是呀，江湖很大，随便去哪里都好，只要爸爸妈妈喜欢，去哪里都可以。”

大家七嘴八舌地说着各个地方，只有郭靖和耶律齐没有说话。

说了一会，大家停下来看黄蓉的意见，毕竟，这么多年来，大家已经习惯了黄蓉拿主意。

黄蓉等大家安静下来后，说：“我是这么想的，咱们去西域，在西域找一个山，以后就在西域安家。”

“也不用带太多人去，就咱们一家人，还有大武小武他们；带一些细软，黄金，就好了。”

“齐儿，你带上过儿留下的玄铁剑。那个到了西域后有用，万一咱们走散了，就在成都汇合，如果成都

也汇合不上，就到昆仑山汇合。”

“我们以后就住在昆仑山附近……”

这时，郭靖突然说话了：“我不去西域…..”

黄蓉一愣：“你想去什么地方？”

郭靖说：“我哪里也不去，就守在襄阳”

黄蓉叹了口气：“按现在这个形势，襄阳最多也就守一个月了。”

郭靖道：“我知道，可我走不了，襄阳破了，我也没地方去了”

黄蓉一愣，沉默了。

短暂的安静后，黄蓉笑了起来。

“这样就简单了，齐儿，你帮我找一些好的铁匠。”

“襄儿，你武功比较好，你带着大武小武他们先去昆仑山，在哪里安顿下来后再回来。”

“靖哥哥，这几天要辛苦你一下，这几年忙，齐儿的降龙十八掌一直没有学完，你多带带他，我也跟着

一起把这些掌法记下来。”

“还有这么多年咱们自己领悟出来的武功，我都整理一下，把它们都记下来。不然以后就没人会了”

“还有你这些年和蒙古军队打仗的经验，我也帮你记录下来。总要给后人留点什么。”

“齐儿，你找人把过儿的玄铁剑改铸成一把刀和一把剑吧，应该会非常锋利。我把这些武功，还有靖哥

哥带兵的经验放在刀剑里，留给后人吧。”

“襄儿，你带着剑走吧，剑里放上你爸爸的降龙十八掌，还有九阴真经，打狗棍法这些武功。”

“刀里放上带兵的谋略吧。刀就让破虏带着。”

“襄儿，你多照看着点你弟弟；破虏，你也多疼着点你姐姐。”

“齐儿，锻好了刀剑后，你也带着芙儿还有孩子们去西域吧，你们住的分开一些。”

耶鲁齐看了看郭靖，看了看黄蓉，又看了看郭芙。

“好，我先去锻造刀剑。芙妹留下来照顾大家。”

两周周后，刀剑锻造好了。黄蓉看着这一对刀剑，把剑交给郭襄，把刀交给郭破虏。

“你们带着大武小武家人去昆仑吧。”

破虏看着黄蓉，说：“我要和爸爸妈妈在一起。”

武敦儒看了看自己的妻子耶律燕，也说：“我们也要和郭伯伯在一起。”

看到郭襄欲言的样子，黄蓉道：“都听我的，襄儿带着剑和大武一家人去昆仑。”

“破虏和小武，你们过几天也出发，分开走。大家昆仑汇合”

“齐儿和芙儿最后走”

“那你和郭伯伯呢？”武敦儒问道。

“我陪着你郭伯伯，守到最后。”

“如果我们都走了，那么，侠义的精神就丢了，反抗的精神就丢了；如果我们都留下，那么，不但大家

都死了，我和你郭伯伯的武功也都失传了，还有你郭伯伯这么多年带兵的经验。”

“所以，你郭伯伯说他不走时，我就想明白了这个。我们传下去精神，你们传下去武功，还有血脉，还

用反抗的力量”

“你们，不管是谁，遇到过儿，和他说，就说我说的，要他尽一切力量反抗蒙古的入侵。”

一个月后，襄阳城破，郭靖、黄蓉被乱箭射死；耶律齐、郭芙死战到最后一刻，死在城下；武敦儒耶

律燕死战扫最后一刻，死在城下；郭破虏带着玄铁刀在逃离途中受伤，不知所踪。

然后城破，吕文焕投降。

郭襄在昆仑山听到消息后，疯一样地赶回襄阳，却连自己父母姐弟的尸体都没有看到。在之后十几年

里，郭襄走遍了山山水水，寻找自己的弟弟郭破虏，寻找弟弟带着的那把屠龙刀。

在四十岁那年，寻找无果后，郭襄在峨眉出家，创立了峨眉派。临死前，郭襄编了十六个字给自己的

弟子：“武林至尊，宝刀屠龙，号令天下，莫敢不从！倚天不出，谁与争锋？”

这时的郭襄多希望自己那个弟弟带着那把刀来到自己面前呀。

五十年后，杨过支持的明教已经是反抗元军暴虐的主力，倚天剑、屠龙刀的出现也加快了元朝的灭

亡。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

28 SEPTEMBER

Harmonize the Immediate and

Long-range Future

A manager must, so to speak, keep his nose to the grindstone

while lifting his eyes to the hills—quite an acrobatic feat.

Amanager has two specific tasks. The first is creation of a true whole that is larger than the sum of

its parts, a productive entity that turns out more than the sum of the resources put into it. The

second specific task of the manager is to harmonize in every decision and action the requirements

of the immediate and of the long-range future. A manager cannot sacrifice

either without endangering the enterprise.

If a manager does not take care of the next hundred days, there will be no next hundred years.

Whatever the manager does should be sound in ex-pediency as well as in basic long-range

objective and principle. And where he cannot harmonize the two time dimensions, he must at least

balance them. He must calculate the sacrifice he imposes on the long-range future of the

enterprise to protect its immediate interests, or the sacrifice he makes today for the sake of

tomorrow. He must limit either sacrifice as much as possible. And he must repair as soon as

possible the damage it inflicts. He lives and acts in two time dimensions, and is responsible for the

perfor-mance of the whole enterprise and of his own component in it.

ACTION POINT: Develop a system of performance measures that will lead to maximizing the total

wealth-producing capacity of your organization. Include both short-term measures and long-term

measures, as well as quantitative and qualitative measures.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

28 SEPTEMBER

Harmonize the Immediate and

Long-range Future

A manager must, so to speak, keep his nose to the grindstone

while lifting his eyes to the hills—quite an acrobatic feat.

Amanager has two specific tasks. The first is creation of a true whole that

is larger than the sum of its parts, a productive entity that turns out more than

the sum of the resources put into it. The second specific task of the manager

is to harmonize in every decision and action the requirements of the

immediate and of the long-range future. A manager cannot sacrifice

either without endangering the enterprise.

If a manager does not take care of the next hundred days, there will be no

next hundred years. Whatever the manager does should be sound in ex-

pediency as well as in basic long-range objective and principle. And where he

cannot harmonize the two time dimensions, he must at least balance them. He

must calculate the sacrifice he imposes on the long-range future of the

enterprise to protect its immediate interests, or the sacrifice he makes today

for the sake of tomorrow. He must limit either sacrifice as much as possible.

And he must repair as soon as possible the damage it inflicts. He lives and

acts in two time dimensions, and is responsible for the perfor-mance of the

whole enterprise and of his own component in it.

ACTION POINT:

Develop a system of performance measures that will lead

to maximizing the total wealth-producing capacity of your organization.

Include both short-term measures and long-term measures, as well as

quantitative and qualitative measures.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

史火龙的抉择

史火龙只丐帮帮主，应该是耶律齐之后几任的。具体是第几任，大家也记不清楚了， 因为这时的丐帮

已经不是大帮了，也没人去记那么清楚了。

丐帮两大神功：降龙十八掌和打狗棒法。到了史火龙时，降龙十八掌只剩下十四章了，而史火龙只学

会了十二章；至于打狗棒法，根本就没提到。曾经的帮主标配，现在成了不可企及的超配。

丐帮的编制还是满的，两个长老，两个龙头，四个人组成了高管团队，再往下八袋，一层一层下去。

编制还在，没有被打乱。只是，丐帮已经不再是天下第一大帮了，这时明教已经起来了，天鹰教也起

来了，还有一些门派的力量也不弱，甚至一些小帮派的势力也不容小觑。

丐帮已经是二流门派了，甚至三流。

这就是史火龙做帮主时面临的丐帮。

要改革，要发展，怎么办？

史火龙本身是个武功高手，加入丐帮前辈称为金银掌。掌力也是小有名气。

后来跟着前帮主学习降龙十八掌，掌力就更厉害了。接任帮主后，史火龙自己已经是一流的武林人

士。

只是丐帮还是二流门派，甚至三流门派。

丐帮要重回第一流门派，如何做？

史火龙觉得，应该从提升自身武功做起。也就是要让自己的武功从第一流变成超一流，就像百年前的

洪七公老帮主那样，跻身当世的五绝。

说做就做，史火龙能想到的第一条路就是想学会降龙十四掌，进一步学会降龙十八掌。

自己的师父只交给了自己十二掌，还有两掌给了自己掌法记录，然后就死掉了。自己想自学会这两掌

吧。

另外，听耶律齐老帮主的遗言，世上还有一份降龙十八掌的完整掌法留存。期待自己可以找到这份掌

法，有了这份掌法，自己的武功就可以跻身到超一流的位置了，丐帮也就会重归一流门派。

恩，就是这么办。

史火龙把帮务交给传功和执法两位长老，还有掌棒、掌钵两位龙头共同处理，自己就去专心修炼武

功。

没想到，练了两年后，不但没有学会那两掌，还走火入魔，上半身瘫痪了。

不过，史火龙还是在全心研究武功，甚至带着妻子到深山里避世修炼，丐帮帮务就由高管层商量着

做。

十几年后，他不但练好了上半身的瘫痪，仿佛也练会了更多的掌法。在他准备出山回归丐帮时，遇到

了成昆。史火龙和成昆掌法对掌法，十二掌后，史火龙重伤，最后不治而亡。

至于丐帮，近几年，八袋弟子陈友谅找了一个和帮主史火龙外貌酷似的人冒充帮主，在假冒帮主和陈

友谅的联合下，丐帮被搞的更加不堪，也更加被武林同道看不起，已经沦落成为打家劫舍的不入流帮

派了。

丐帮在衰落的路上又前进了一步。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

29 SEPTEMBER

Misdirection by Specialization

“I am building a cathedral.”

An old story tells of three stonecutters who were asked what they were doing.

The first replied, “I am making a living.”

The second kept on hammering while he said, “I am doing the best job of stonecutting in the entire

country.”

The third one looked up with a visionary gleam in his eyes and said, “I am building a cathedral.”

The third man is, of course, the true manager.

The first man knows what he wants to get out of the work and manages to do so.

He is likely to give a “fair day’s work for a fair day’s pay.”

But he is not a manager and will never be one.

It is the second man who is a problem.

Workmanship is essential: in fact, an organization demoralizes if it does not demand of its

members the highest workmanship they are capable of.

But there is always a danger that the true workman, the true professional, will believe that he is

accomplishing something when in effect he is just polishing stones or collecting footnotes.

Workmanship must be encouraged in the business enterprise. But it must always be related to the

needs of the whole.

ACTION POINT:

Develop a process whereby each person in the organization understands his or her contribution to

producing the products and services of the enterprise.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

29 SEPTEMBER

Misdirection by Specialization

“I am building a cathedral.”

An old story tells of three stonecutters who were asked what they were

doing. The first replied, “I am making a living.” The second kept on

hammering while he said, “I am doing the best job of stonecutting in the

entire country.” The third one looked up with a visionary gleam in his eyes

and said, “I am building a cathedral.” The third man is, of course, the true

manager. The first man knows what he wants to get out of the work and

manages to do so. He is likely to give a “fair day’s work for a fair day’s pay.”

But he is not a manager and will never be one. It is the second man who is

Aproblem. Workmanship is essential: in fact, an organization demoralizes if it

does not demand of its members the highest workmanship they are ca-pable

of. But there is always a danger that the true workman, the true pro-fessional,

will believe that he is accomplishing something when in effect he is just

polishing stones or collecting footnotes. Workmanship must be encouraged in

the business enterprise. But it must always be related to the

needs of the whole.

ACTION POINT:

Develop a process whereby each person in the organiza-

tion understands his or her contribution to producing the products and ser-

vices of the enterprise.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

山东人的智慧

这几年山东的负面新闻不少，有山大女学生的，有青岛大虾的，还有其他一些莫名其妙的。

前几天我看新闻，突然看到一个给救火车开锁后收费的新闻，当时没留意。今天查了一下，居然也是

山东的，山东寿光的。说的是今年8月13日的事情。

8月13日，一辆消防救灾车辆在山东寿光市纪台镇落入水沟，车辆进水导致锁具故障。随后，消防员联

系了寿光“七个五”开锁中心，服务人员开锁后开价500元。最终，经过还价，消防救援队支付了300元

服务费。

有附近群众却表示，寿光日常开车门费用在50元至80元之间。

此事却仍然引发民众强烈指责。随后市场监督管理局接入，经过调查后对开锁中心进行了处罚：没收

违法所得，可并处5000元罚款。

同日（8月14日），开锁中心公开发布《致歉书》。

开锁中心保证马上退还开锁服务费300元的同时，决定之后免费为所有抗震救灾车辆提供开锁服务，免

费为所有受灾群众提供开锁服务，免费为寿光市60岁以上老人提供开锁服务。并且恳请社会各界人士

的监督！

虽然民众还是有点不依不饶，这个事情也算过去了，民众得到了一次小小的胜利。

看到这个事情，我想起了前几天听馒头说论语讲的一个故事。也是发生在山东，不过是发生2500多年

前。

也就是孔子的年代，

在孔子年代，鲁国人是很幸福的， 因为鲁国有一条法令：国人如发现鲁人在他国为奴者，可以赎回，

并回国兑领赎金及领赏。

因为有这条法令，在当时的全国，很少有鲁国国民为奴，因为只要一发现，就会被人救回到鲁国去。

毕竟不用自己花钱，还可以得到一些奖励，还有一些名。

孔子有一个学生叫做子贡，子贡在外发现了一个沦为奴隶的鲁国人，把他赎了回来，回国后却没去找

政府报销。

孔子知道后很生气，直接骂子贡说：“端木赐（子贡的名字），你个二货。从今往后，鲁国人就不肯再

替沦为奴隶的同胞赎身了。”

为什么呢？因为子贡拔高了道德标准。救人后“我去报销吧，那么我的品行人们会质疑；不报销吧，我

自己又付出了金钱，又付出了精力，何苦了。”“干脆不救了吧”

孔子的另一个学生子路。有一次，子路救了一个溺水的人，人家送他一头牛答谢，他高高兴兴收下

了。孔子说：你这小子不错！比子贡那小子抢夺了，以后救人的会越来越多的。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

30 SEPTEMBER

Compensation Structure

Compensation must always try to balance recognition of the individual with stability and maintenance of the group.

People have to be paid, but every compensation system is liable to misdirect.

Compensation always expresses status, both within the enter-prise and in society.

It entails judgments on a person’s worth as much as on performance.

It is emotionally tied to all our ideas of fairness, justice, and equity.

Money is, of course, quantitative.

But the money in any compensa- tion system expresses the most intangible, but also the most sensitive, val-ues and qualities.

No attempt at a “scientific formula” for compensation can therefore be completely successful.

The best possible compensation plan is of necessity a compromise among the various functions and meanings of compensation, for the indi- vidual as well as for the group.

Even the best plan will still disorganize as well as organize, misdirect as well as direct, and encourage the wrong as well as the right behavior.

The preference should be for simple compensa- tion systems rather than for complex ones.

It should be for compensation systems that allow judgment to be used and that enable pay to be fitted to the job of the individual rather than impose one formula on everybody.

All one can do is to watch lest the compensation system reward the wrong be-havior, emphasize the wrong results, and direct people away from perfor-mance for the common good.

ACTION POINT:

Develop a compensation system that rewards individual performance while balancing individual rewards with rewards that help maintain the continuity of the entire organization as a whole.

Management: Tasks, Responsibilities, Practices

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

我要做出自己的极致PPT

书友会成立了一个PPT小组，是艳红说要成立的。艳红听了隗洁的一次分享后，就决定成立这个PPT小

组。

PPT，本来是一种文件格式，是微软的PowerPoint的文件格式，后来成了一个代名词，就像PS代表修

图一样，PPT代表的是演示，通过演示来表达自己。

我接触PPT非常早，早到可以暴露自己的年龄了。好吧，我是1995年接触PPT，当时在上海的一个学

校里给小孩子们讲PPT，而我做助教。

再后来，微软把word、excel、ppt组成了一个小分队，PPT也就成了办公组件中的一个小角色了。毕

竟，对于办公室来说，word和excel才是主流。办公自动化考的就是word和excel么。（什么？你没听

过办公自动化？恭喜你，你应该很小）。

我是一个码农，在公司，在身边，电脑出什么问题都会有人来找我。这应该是所有码农的经历吧。不

过，有一个事别人肯定不会来找码农，就是word、excel不会用了。

很久很久前就传说，在公司里，最不会用word和excel的就是码农。而最会用excel的是谁的？

对，是会计。

所以，我一直“会”用word，后来有了excel后，觉得excel和word有啥区别呀，不就多了一些表格么？

word也可以做表格呀。
