“拼缝的”。有时问他们行业是，他们会用一种隐晦的方式来给你描述：我是财富管理的，我是餐饮行

业的，我是做地产的，我是做知识付费的。

我听完他（她）的介绍后，你还是不清楚他是做什么的。财富管理是什么呢？什么叫餐饮行业？什么

叫地产？你如何做知识付费？

其实，这是一个经济时代，在这个时代，商业拥有非常高的地位。这个时代鼓励个人通过合法的商业

手段获得利益，并且，这种鼓励是最高的鼓励。

这又是一个无限细分的时代，也是一个无限合作的时代。任何你做的一件事，只要是对别人有利的，

可以帮助到别人的，就可以获得相应的报酬，而这个，是非常光荣的。

我今天和一个朋友说，你下次给别人介绍是，一定要说：“我是保险业务员，你可以找我买保险。”这

个描述清晰，简洁。就像何三七说的：“馄饨一碗十文钱”。

在这个时代，用心做商业，很美。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

18 OCTOBER

Capitalism Justified

Capitalism：

[ U ] an economic system in which a country’s businesses and industry are controlled and run for profit by private

owners rather than by the government

资本主义

Justified：

(in doing sth) having a good reason for doing sth

（做某事）有正当理由的

Capitalism as a social order and as a creed is the expression of the belief in economic progress as

leading toward the freedom and equality of the individual in the free and equal society.

creed：

信念；原则；纲领；宗教信仰

a set of principles or religious beliefs

Capitalism expects the free and equal society to result from the enthronement of private profit as

supreme ruler of social behavior.

enthronement：

N-COUNT The enthronement of a king, queen, emperor, or bishop is a ceremony in which they officially take

on their role.

supreme：

highest in rank or position

（级别或地位）最高的，至高无上的

Capitalism did not, of course, invent the “profit motive.”

motive：

动机；原因；目的

(for sth) a reason for doing sth

Profit has always been one of the main motivating forces of the individual and will always be—

regardless of the social order in which one lives.

But the capitalist creed was the first and only social creed that valued the profit motive positively

as the means by which the ideal free and equal society would be automatically realized.

All previous creeds had regarded the profit motive as socially destructive, or at least neutral.

destructive：

引起破坏（或毁灭）的；破坏（或毁灭）性的

neutral：adj. 中立的，中性的；中立国的；非彩色的

causing destruction or damage

Capitalism has, therefore, to endow the economic sphere with independence and autonomy,

which means that economic activities must not be subjected to noneconomic considerations, but

must rank higher.

endow：

（向学校等机

[ VN ] to give a large sum of money to a school, a college or another institution to provide it with an income

构）捐钱，捐赠，资助

sphere：an area of activity, influence or interest; a particular section of society 范围；领域；阶层；界

All social energies have to be concentrated upon the promotion of economic ends, because

economic progress carries the promise of the social millennium.

This is capitalism: and without this social end it has neither sense nor justification.

ACTION POINT: Think through to what extent your own economic activity or that of your

organization contributes to social ends.

The End of Economic Man

18 OCTOBER

Capitalism Justified

Capitalism as a social order and as a creed is the expression of the belief in

economic progress as leading toward the freedom and equality of the individual

in the free and equal society.

Capitalism expects the free and equal society to result from the en-

thronement of private profit as supreme ruler of social behavior. Cap-italism

did not, of course, invent the “profit motive.” Profit has always been one of

the main motivating forces of the individual and will always be—re-gardless

of the social order in which one lives. But the capitalist creed was the first

and only social creed that valued the profit motive positively as the means by

which the ideal free and equal society would be automatically re-alized. All

previous creeds had regarded the profit motive as socially de-

structive, or at least neutral.

Capitalism has, therefore, to endow the economic sphere with inde-

pendence and autonomy, which means that economic activities must not

be subjected to noneconomic considerations, but must rank higher. All so-

cial energies have to be concentrated upon the promotion of economic

ends, because economic progress carries the promise of the social millen-

nium. This is capitalism: and without this social end it has neither sense

nor justification.

ACTION POINT:

Think through to what extent your own economic activ-ity

or that of your organization contributes to social ends.

The End of Economic Man

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

你有“fuck you money”么？

一

今天早上看到一个视频，是一个叫刘玉玲的女生面对采访时说的话：

【插入图片】

“我父亲教过我一件事，一切的本质都是生意。所以我为了赚钱努力工作，就是为了有一笔‘Fuck

You’的钱。这笔钱就是用在我不想被别人逼着做一件事，或者被人炒掉，我可以把钱甩出来，老娘有

钱，老娘不在乎，Fuck You！”

【插入视频】

二

这是一个商业时代，在这个时代，一切都是商业的，规则简单透明。虽然也有“潜规则”，商业规则还

是主流，只要准从商业规则，则可以让自己生活的很开心。

三

在这个时代，每个人都要参与商业活动，也就是说要赚钱。因为，只有赚钱，你才可以生活；也就

说，只要赚钱，你就可以生活，而且生活的不错。

四

赚钱的方式很多，而且越来越多。以前是三百六十行，现在是三千六百行都不止。幸运的是，你做哪

一行都可以赚钱，而且，只要你足够专业，你都可以过上中等的生活。

做工人可以，做农民也可以，做医生也可以，做保险业务员也可以，做银行的理财顾问也可以，做心

理咨询师也可以，帮人介绍工作也可以，帮人跑腿也可以，帮人出主意也可以。

几乎你能想到的动脑、动手、动身体的任何行为，都可以赚到钱。

五

前提是你要专业，也就是，你要在某一个领域用心。这就需要你在一个行业内的沉淀。对于保险业务

员来说，你需要了解一类保单细节，需要了解一类人的细节，需要了解用户的需求，需要了解每一个

保单的底层逻辑，它们解决的问题以及客户购买时的心理历程。

如果你在卖课，卖一些线上的付费课程。你需要了解这个课程的内容，需要了解这个课程的目标群

体，需要了解目标群体的需求，以及购买时的心理历程，以及购买后的期望。

如果你在做咨询，你要多看一些书，了解一些理论，你要多接触客户，了解客户的实际情况，你还要

了解现实的环境，了解对应行业的发展，最后，你要给出客户可选的建议。这些都需要你花费很大的

精力。

只要你专业，你就可以做的比别人好，只要你足够用心，任何一个行业都可以让你赚到你需要的钱。

六

或许你觉得另一个行业可以赚跟多的钱，你可以尝试，可以了解，甚至可以进入。不过，如果你的目

的是赚钱，那么你要知道，当你把精力分散到一个新的行业时，你的旧的行业的收入就会减少，整体

大体差不多。

七

当然，也有可能会多一些。

问题是，你是一个人，一个来这个世界上生活的人。这是一个美好的时代，这是商业时代，在这个时

代，你需要的是找到一个商业机会用来赚钱，赚到钱后，你就可以按自己期望的方式生活了。

赚钱并不是你的目的，生活才是。对于赚钱这件事来说，你只需要在一到两个行业就好了。至于其他

的，你应该是“消费”。

八

在自己的领域，在自己的行业，你应该非常用心，努力、全心全力地区赚钱，这个努力，不管如果做

都是正常的。既然你是理财顾问，那就去了解财富运行的所有机制，那就去了解这个时代你的客户群

里的财富获取、使用情况，让自己变得非常专业。在这个行业之外，那里有一笔不错的钱，对不起，

我不要。

九

一切都是生意，一切又都是生活。我有我的领域，我有我的专业，我在我的专业赚钱。其他领域，我

是消费者。当我不开心时，我可以说“fuck you”，而这个“fuck you”的能力就来自你的“fuck you

money”，来自你专业的积累。

十

你可能很自豪自己可以在几个领域赚到钱，问题是，你真的希望自己的钱被分的那么碎么？你有没有

想过，你一天中，有多少时间在“赚钱”，多少时间在“生活”？

十一

对于职业之外的事情，你有能力说“fuck you”么？你有没有想过？你之所以被职业外的事情诱惑，只是

因为你的职业不够专业。

少林方丈玄慈对本寺的七十二绝技也有过描述：“各位大师，敝寺虽有七十二项绝技，但一来每一项功

法均极难练，纵是天资卓异之人，一生亦不易练成一项，何况各项绝技练到精处高处，总之不过在武

学上胜人一筹而已，既能以甲门功夫胜人，便不必再以乙门功夫胜人，至于丙门、丁门，更加不必去

练了。”

十二

你有职业么？你在你的职业专业么？你的职业可以给你“fuck you money ”么？还是你不得不被各种行

业，各种碎钱“fuck”？

投票

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

19 OCTOBER

Moving Beyond Capitalism

I believe it is socially and morally unforgivable when managers reap huge profits for themselves but

fire workers.

reap：[ VN ] to obtain sth, especially sth good, as a direct result of sth that you have done 取得

（成果）；收获

I am for the free market. Even though it doesn’t work too well, nothing else works at all.

But I have serious reservations about capitalism as a system because it idolizes economics as the

be-all and end-all of life.

It is one-dimensional. For example, I have often advised managers that a 20–1 salary ratio between

senior executives and rank-and-file white-collar workers is the limit beyond which they cannot go if

they don’t want resentment and falling morale to hit their companies.

Today, I believe it is socially and morally unforgivable when managers reap huge profits for

themselves but fire workers.

As societies, we will pay a heavy price for the contempt this generates among middle managers

and workers.

In short, whole dimensions of what it means to be a human being and treated as one are not

incorporated into the economic calculus of cap-italism.

For such a myopic system to dominate other aspects of life is not good for any society.

ACTION POINT:

Have executives in your organization reaped huge profits for themselves while laying off significant

numbers of workers?

Enumerate the ways these policies have led to contempt and falling morale.

Managing in the Next Society

【原书原文】

Moving Beyond Capitalism?

This interview was conducted by Nathan Gardels, editor of New Perspectives Quarterly, in the

author’s

office in Claremont, California. It was based on the author’s specifying the topics and the interv

iewer’s

questions. The author himself edited the interviewer’s draft into the final text. The interview ap

peared in New Perspectives Quarterly in the spring 1998 issue.

Of late, some of capitalism’s biggest boosters, people such as yourself and the financier George

Soros, have become its biggest critics.

What is your critique?

I am for the free market. Even though it doesn’t work too well, nothing else

works at all. But I have serious reservations about capitalism as a system because

it idolizes economics as the be-all and end-all of life. It is one-dimensional.

For example, I have often advised managers that a 20–1 salary ratio is the

limit beyond which they cannot go if they don’t want resentment and falling morale to hit

their companies. I worried back in the 1930s that the great

inequality generated by the Industrial Revolution would result in so much despair

that something like fascism would take hold. Unfortunately, I was right.

Today, I believe it is socially and morally unforgivable when managers reap huge profits for

themselves but fire workers. As societies, we will pay a heavy price for the contempt this generates

among the middle managers and workers.

In short, whole dimensions of what it means to be a human being and treated as one are not

incorporated into the economic calculus of capitalism. For such a

myopic system to dominate other aspects of life is not good for any society.

With regard to the market, there are several serious problems with the theory itself.

First of all, the theory assumes there is one homogeneous market. In reality,

there are three overlapping markets that, by and large, don’t interchange: an international

market in money and information, national markets, and local markets.

Most of what passes for transnational economic money, of course, is only virtual money.

The London interbank market each day has a greater volume of activity in

dollar terms than the whole world would need for a year to finance all economic transactions.

This is functionless money. It cannot possibly earn any return since it serves no function. It has no

purchasing power. It is, therefore, totally speculative and prone to panics as it rushes here and

there to earn that last 64th of 1 percent.

Then, there is a large national economy which is not exposed to international commerce. Some 24

percent of U.S. economic activity is exposed to trade. In Japan, it is only 8 percent.

Then there is the local economy. The hospital near my home has very high- quality care and is very

competitive. But it does not compete with any hospital forty miles away in Los Angeles. The

effective market area for hospitals in the

U.S. is about ten miles because, for some obscure reason no economist would be

able to figure out, people like to be close to their sick mothers.

Also, what drives markets has changed. The economic center of gravity shifted sometime during

this century. In the nineteenth century, with steel and

steam, supply generated demand. Since the Great Depression, however, the tables have turned: In

traditional products, from home construction to cars, demand must come before supply—

although this is not yet true today of information and electronics, which stimulate demand.

Beyond this definition of markets, the truly profound issue is that market theory is based on an

assumption of equilibrium and thus cannot accommodate change, let alone innovation.

Rather, the real pattern of economic activity, as Joseph Schumpeter

recognized as long ago as 1911, is “a moving disequilibrium” caused by the process of

creative destruction as new markets with new products and new demand are made at the

expense of old ones.

Market outcomes cannot, therefore, be explained in terms of what the theory would have

predicted. The market is in fact not a predictable system, but inherently unstable. And if it is not

predictable, you cannot base your behavior

on it. That is a pretty serious limitation for a theory of human behavior.

All we can say is that, in the end, any long-term equilibrium is the result of a lot of short-term

adaptations to market signals.

This, finally, is the strength of the market: It is a disciplinarian for the short

term. By providing feedback through prices, it discourages you from squandering

time and resources going off in all directions like King Arthur’s knights.

The old idea was that if you rode on long enough you would run into

something. The market tells you that if you don’t run into something in five

weeks, you better change course or do something else.

Beyond the short term, the market is useless. You know, I have sat in on more than my share of

research planning for large companies. Fundamentally, this

activity is an act of faith. When the chief financial officer asks, as he always does,

“What will be the return?” on this or that project, the only answer is “We will know in ten years.”

Years ago you wrote about pension fund ownership of the American economy, calling it “capitalism

sans capitalists” where workers’ retirement funds own the means of production.

Today, this dispersion of wealth has gone even further through the explosion of mutual funds—

more than 51 percent of Americans own shares of stock.

Have we arrived at mass capitalism or postcapitalism?

Well, to call it postcapitalism is merely to say we don’t know what to call it.

You also can’t call it economic democracy since there is no organized form of governance

associated with this mass ownership.

What is certain is that it is a totally new phenomenon in history.

My gardener, who is not a wealthy man, takes the “money markets” section

of the Wall Street Journal I put out for him at the back door every week to guide his

stock investments.

A friend of mine who works with a regional financial service that has 2

million accounts told me recently that his average investor has gone from putting

0,000 per year to 5,000 per year in his mutual fund.

Perhaps it is becoming true that capitalists don’t matter anymore. In earlier periods of the adoration

of the rich, there were strongly voiced opinions either

that “we need the rich for capital formation” or “the rich are just exploiting us

all.” One doesn’t hear either of these opinions anymore.

J. P. Morgan once mattered to the American economy. At his peak, he had enough liquid capital to

finance all capital needs in America for four months.

Adjusting for inflation, J. P. Morgan probably had a little less than a third of what Bill Gates has

today. Such wealth possessed by one man has not been seen

in the world since the time of the great Khan of China. But Gates’s 0 billion

could only finance the American economy for less than one day.

Bill Gates is important because of the Microsoft company he built and the

software we use. As a rich man, he is totally irrelevant. How he spends or wastes his money will

have no impact on the American economy. It is a drop in the bucket.

The wealth that makes the difference in America today is that held by tens of millions of

small investors.

Historically, state socialism has failed to produce wealth or efficiently provide social services. Yet

capitalism ignores any other dimension of life besides economic exchange. And, as you say, the

market is only short-term. How does society, then, manage in the long term?

We now know that we need three sectors, not two. Not just government and business, but what

people now call the civil society or third sector in between.

Indeed, I believe that the realistic alternative to the socialist delusion on one

hand, and the pure market on the other, combines the dispersed ownership of the

economy through pension and mutual funds with a “third” nonprofit sector to

cope with community needs from health care to tutoring students.

The idea that some of my Republican friends have that we can do without government is just silly. It

is an understandable reaction because of the postwar belief that government could take care of all

community needs.

But we have learned that government, like any other tool, is good for some

things but not good for others. It is important, for example, for collective defense

and for raising the financial means for infrastructure through taxes.

But, just as I am unlikely to do well trying to cut my toenails with a hammer, government is

incompetent at fulfilling community needs. Everything a state does, it has to do on a national level.

It cannot experiment or adapt to the local conditions of a community.

The state tends to define a problem in a standard way and then monopolizes

the solution. But what works in St. Louis usually doesn’t work even in Kansas City, let alone New

York or Los Angeles.

With its singular profit motive, of course, the market simply has no interest or capacity to cope with

social problems.

Though people think of me mainly as a management consultant for business, I have spent much of

my time for fifty years consulting for nonprofit

organizations. Fifteen years ago, there were only three hundred thousand taxexempt nonprofit groups registered with the IRS, including such well-known groups as the

American Heart Association and the American Lung Association. Now there are over 1 million.

I also helped set up a foundation for nonprofit management, run by the former national executive of

the Girl Scouts. The idea was simple: These organizations are not so much mismanaged as

unmanaged. Without market discipline, they need a focused mission and a results orientation as

their bottom line.

One of the problems our foundation has had is the overwhelming demand from countries as

diverse as Japan, Brazil, Argentina, and Poland. They all need social sector institutions desperately

—from the establishment of nursing

associations to battered women’s shelters to crop education for peasants in places like Patagonia.

Why is the social sector growing in Japan, where the community has been so strong?

Well, two things are happening. First, the traditional community structure is

crumbling. Second, educated women who have worked for a few years, then left

work to have children, who then go off to school, are bored.

What kind of social problems does Japan have? When you reach fifty-five

years of age in Japan, you are essentially thrown on the dung heap—even though you will probably

live thirty years longer. So, the elderly organize clubs, from

sports to ikebana flower arranging, to keep themselves occupied.

One of the most successful new social sector groups in Japan engages in that most unJapanese of activities: “meals on wheels” for the elderly who can’t get out.

Young people don’t take care of the elderly anymore. Yet, the government fought the

establishment of the meals-on-wheels program because it meant they

had to admit their old people were not doing so well. Indeed, this is a blot on the Japanese honor.

But it is a fact.

There is also a tremendous need among teenagers and schoolage children to drive them to and

from school, to supervise homework, and tutor those who do not make the top grades.

Nobody outside Japan seems to know that while 20 percent of Japanese

students excel, the rest who don’t are simply forgotten. The social sector tries to provide for these

kids.

There are also conversation and reading classes in English for Japanese women who learned a little

in high school or at work and want to maintain it. There are now over 185,000 of these circles, even

in small towns.

In Japan now there is even an Alcoholics Anonymous Association. I don’t know how big they

are so far, but sometimes it seems every salaryman in the country could become a member.

In the U.S., though, the size of the social problems means they just can’t be taken care of by

voluntary associations, can they?

Perhaps not entirely. But the scope of activities is just tremendous. More than

50 percent of Americans work at least four hours a week in a voluntary association of some sort, in

the church or the community.

And the solutions to community problems they come up with are highly creative. I have come over

the years to learn a very important lesson: Practical examples of how to solve social problems

matter greatly because others will replicate them.

To this end, each year the Drucker Foundation gives a prize to a voluntary association to highlight

their example so they can be replicated.

One year, we gave the prize to a very small group run by an immigrant who

found a way to bring together the worst, most unproductive welfare mothers and the most

seriously disabled children. This led to a situation where the disabled were cared for and, in time,

the welfare mothers became qualified to be fully employed and well paid.

There is another project we highlighted by a Lutheran church in St. Louis. In

their area, they found that about two-fifths of the homeless, mostly families, need

very little to get back on their feet.

The first thing the church did was assess what homeless families needed most. The answer

was self-respect.

So the members of the congregation would buy dilapidated houses and find volunteers to refurbish

them into comfortable middle-class homes. Then they

moved the homeless family in. That by itself changed their outlook on life. Then

designated church members would help the family with their bills and in finding work. In the end,

about 80 percent of the families in their program went permanently off any kind of assistance.

Then there are organizations such as the Girl Scouts that are reaching new levels of participation. A

few years ago they were down to about five hundred thousand volunteers. Today they are up to

about nine hundred thousand.

The old volunteer was usually a middle-class housewife bored at home. The new volunteer is more

often than not a professional woman who has postponed

having children, but likes to be with girls on the weekend after having worked all week in a

male environment.

For most of the last twenty-five years, I have worked with the fast-growing Protestant

megachurches in the U.S., which I believe are one of the most

significant social phenomena in the world today. They teach community activism and encourage

people to live their faith by taking action to improve the lives of others.

While the traditional churches may be dying in some ways, in others they are being transformed.

Take the Catholic Church in America. Pope John Paul II has been very careful

to place conservative bishops in the American church because it frightens him. It is not so much

the theological problems, married priests, and ordained women that bother him, but the enormous

upsurge of activity in the dioceses that is laydriven and not controlled by the bishop.

In one of the larger Midwestern dioceses that I know, there used to be seven

hundred priests; now there are barely more than two hundred and fifty. There are

almost no nuns now—but there are twenty-five hundred laywomen. Every parish

has a lay administrator who is a woman.

All the priest does is say Mass and dispense the sacraments. Women run the rest of the show

entirely as volunteers. That is a long way from the days of the altar girl.

Why does the U.S. have such a large and vital third sector when compared to other countries,

including other Western countries?

No other country has anywhere near the scale of activity the U.S. has in the nonprofit sector

because, elsewhere essentially, the civil servants of the modern national state destroyed the

community sector.

In France it is almost a crime to do anything in the community. The

voluntary sector in Victorian England was quite large. It dealt with poverty, with crime, with

prostitution, with housing. But in the twentieth century the welfare state almost destroyed it.

In Europe the basic struggle was to free the state from the domination of the church, which

explains why continental Europe has such an enormous anticlerical tradition.

In the U.S., it was the other way around. When Jonathan Edwards established

the doctrine of separation of church and state around 1740, it was in order to free

the church from the state. Anticlericalism has never had a place in this country.

Because of this freedom, the U.S. developed a tradition of religious pluralism and nongovernmental

churches. And with pluralism, there was competition

among the denominations for members. Out of that competition came a tradition

of community involvement which doesn’t exist in other countries.

Aside from Jefferson’s University of Virginia, all colleges in the U.S. were

denominational until Oberlin was established in 1833.

19 OCTOBER

Moving Beyond Capitalism

I believe it is socially and morally unforgivable when managers

reap huge profits for themselves but fire workers.

Iam for the free market. Even though it doesn’t work too well, nothing else

works at all. But I have serious reservations about capitalism as a sys-tem

because it idolizes economics as the be-all and end-all of life. It is one-

dimensional. For example, I have often advised managers that a 20–1 salary ratio

between senior executives and rank-and-file white-collar workers is the limit

beyond which they cannot go if they don’t want resentment and

falling morale to hit their companies.

Today, I believe it is socially and morally unforgivable when managers

reap huge profits for themselves but fire workers. As societies, we will

pay a heavy price for the contempt this generates among middle managers

and workers. In short, whole dimensions of what it means to be a human

being and treated as one are not incorporated into the economic calculus

of cap-italism. For such a myopic system to dominate other aspects of life

is not good for any society.

ACTION POINT:

Have executives in your organization reaped huge profits for

themselves while laying off significant numbers of workers? Enumerate the

ways these policies have led to contempt and falling morale.

Managing in the Next Society

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

小宝的特别之处

小宝是金庸武侠小说最后一个主人公。

有人说《鹿鼎记》是金庸最棒的一个小说，是武侠小说的巅峰；有人说《鹿鼎记》是金庸最烂的一部

武侠小说，甚至都不能算武侠小说。

对于小宝这个人，大家的观点也算两级。有人特别喜欢他，比如我，有人非常不喜欢他，觉得这么一

个流氓，居然成了主角，又贪财有好色，手段卑鄙，居然风生水起，非常不符合我们的价值观。

那么小宝究竟是不是侠？小宝的武如何？《鹿鼎记》究竟是不是武侠小说？为什么金庸写到韦小宝后

就收手了？

这些我也没有答案，不过，我们可以探讨一下，探讨一下小宝的特别之处。

金庸有15部武侠小说，那就有15个主角，咱们列一下：

有人会说天龙八部的主角应该是段誉，所以，你按段誉理解也是对的。咱们看一下这些主角有哪些特

点呢?

首先，大家的武功都不低，都是一流水平的，甚至是超一流水平的，除了韦小宝。

陈家洛、萧峰等出场就满配；郭靖、杨过等打怪升级，一步一步走向人生巅峰。而小宝呢？到最后也

就是有一个逃之夭夭的法宝。

再说主观能动性，大家都是愿意学习武功的，都是主动拜师的，狗杂种虽然无意识，可是有人教他，

他还是很愿意学习的。而且学习的不错。至于那些配角，如杨康、林平之、武烈、朱长龄等，为了学

习到一个武功更是费尽心机，丧尽天良，结果还是学不会。

而韦小宝呢？先是茅十八愿意教他武功，他不学，因为不想低一辈；后来海大富教他学武功，为了和

康熙打架，他多少学了一点，也是能偷懒就偷懒；后来陈近南收了做了弟子，教他学武功，陈近南的

武功是非常高的，结果他还是不学，因为懒。

再后来，洪教主教他几招，逼着他练习，他算学会了一点；九难收他为弟子后，也教他一些武功，愣

是学不会，主要还是不用心。

还好，九难因材施教，教给了他神行九变，小宝勉强学了一两层。算有了活命的基本功。

不过，这个基本功也没用过，为什么呢？一会说。

再说一下金庸这些主角在江湖上的地位。陈家洛是红花会大当家的，有头有脸；萧峰是丐帮帮主、南

院大王，有头有脸；令狐冲是恒山派掌门，魔教任盈盈的爱侣，有头有脸；就连狗杂种也是长乐帮的

帮主，有头有脸。

那么韦小宝呢？当了天地会青木堂堂主，原因是他在清宫做太监；做了神龙教五龙使，因为洪教主喜

欢他；做了御膳房总管应该康熙喜欢他。

应该是，韦小宝的所有职位，都是因为别人的原因。如果陈近南不喜欢他，他就做不了香主，如果洪

教主不喜欢他，他就做不了白龙使，如果康熙不喜欢他，他什么都做不了。

令狐冲呢？任盈盈不喜欢他有问题么？哪怕天下人都不喜欢他，又有什么问题呢？

萧峰也是这样，他的武力、智力足以对抗整个世界。

这中间有区别么？

我仔细分析了一下，发现还是有区别的，而且区别很大。

以萧峰为例，是很有权势的人，即使不是丐帮帮主，不是南院大王，他还是北乔峰。他的武功，他的

智谋让他在那个武侠的世界里拥有了“绝对的权力”。

就像令狐冲、张无忌、郭靖、袁承志这些人，他们的武力可以直接改变江湖的格局。而不需要借助其

他的。

这种武力带来的权力，我定义为“绝对的权力”。

韦小宝没有这个权力，甚至他也从来没有追求过这个权力，甚至他在回避这个权力。为什么呢？

因为韦小宝有另一个权力，这个权力由两部分组成：义和钱。

是的，这是两个完全没关系的事情，可是韦小宝就有了这两个东西。

首先，韦小宝是非常讲义气的，他对对他好的人是真好，不管是茅十八，还是陈近南还是康熙还是九

难。小宝对他们都很真诚。所以，小宝真心地交了很多朋友，这些朋友也都真心对他。

另外，就是小宝有钱。

不要小看这个，如果没有钱，小宝的义气会显得很单薄。

咱们先看看小宝有多少钱：

小宝在宫里赌博先是赚了点小钱，然后把钱借给了一个小太监，这是小宝用钱获得一个主要资源。这

个资源让他有机会第一次帮到了康熙，为后来的青云直上提供了基础。

后来，小宝奉命抄鳌拜的家，分得了四十六万六千两，有了这笔钱，小宝待人接物就大方多了。也就

更容易建立宫里的人脉圈子了。

在之后，小宝的钱花的越来越多，各种路子也越来越野。当然，这中间，他的智商也起了决定性的左

右。不过，钱确实给他铺了很多路。

最后，小宝告老还乡，这时的小宝已经没有了官府和江湖的位置，不过，他还是有很多钱，20多岁后

的韦小宝后续会如何生活呢？可以想象，小宝的那些钱为他以后的生活铺平了道路。

在小宝之前，江湖上的侠客，那些有权力的侠客，他们的权力来源只有一个，就是“武力”，他们必须

拥有绝对的武力，才可以拥有足够的权力。但这种绝对的权力，让他们没办法退出江湖。

就像东方不败，他确实永远不败，因为对于他们来说，败就是死。

而到了韦小宝时代，拥有权力不再需要武力了。财富也可以，钱就可以。

萧峰没钱了，他的第一方法就是去抢；令狐冲没钱了，也是去抢。而小宝不一样，他一直有钱。

所以，小宝并不需要武力，因为小宝有武力能带来的东西：权力，却没有武力的后遗症：不能退出。

这就是“钱”的价值，在小宝之前的江湖，你进入后，就一条死路，或者食人，或者被吃。而小宝之后

的江湖，权力可以很柔和，有钱就行了。

最后，咱们看看小宝是如何用钱的：

韦小宝暂免一刀之厄，但想这两位姑娘定是守在门口，自己只要踏出妓院门口一步，立时便给她们杀

了，叫道：“大家别乱动，每个人十两银子，人人都有，决不落空。”众妓一听，立时静了下来。

韦小宝一进寺门，便取出一千两银票，交给住持，说道：“暂借宝刹休息，一切不可多问。问一句话，

扣十两银子。一句不问，这一千两银子都是香金。如问了一百零一句，你倒找我十两，不折不扣，童

叟无欺。”

那住持乍得巨金，又惊又喜，当即喏喏连声，问道：“师兄要……”话到口边，突然一怔，忙改口道：

“……要喝杯茶了。”匆匆入内端茶。他本来想问“师兄要不要喝杯茶？”总算尚有急智，临时改口，省下

了十两银子。

韦小宝哈哈大笑，说道：“来人哪，拿五十两银子，赏给这个胆小如鼠的朋友。喂，这些希你妈的河，

希你爸的山，你要是出去跟人说了，给我一知道，立即追还你五十两银子，连本带利，一共是一百五

十两银子。”

那笔帖式大喜过望，他一个月饷银，也不过十二两银子，都统大人这一赏就是五十两，忙请安道谢，

连称：“卑职决不敢乱说。”心想：“本钱五十两，利息却要一百两。我的妈啊，好重的利息，杀了头我

也还不起。”

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

【素材】

韦小宝贪污清单：

1、与索额图奉旨查抄鳌拜家产，共抄得二百三十五万三千四百一十八两，却只上报一百三十五万三千

四百一十八两，那多出来的一百万两银子，两人偷偷分掉了，扣除了上下打点的支出，韦小宝分得四

十五万两。（第五回）

2、尚膳监两名太监行贿：二千两银票。

康亲王送的大礼：大宛宝马“玉花骢”。（第七回）

3、索额图变卖鳌拜的家产，为讨好韦小宝，又多给了一万六千五百两银。

掌管尚膳监的“油水”：每个月八百两银子。（第九回）

4、在康亲王府，江百胜故意输钱给他：七百两银子。

吴应熊的贿赂：一对翡翠鸡；两串一百粒的明珠；四百两金票。康熙前期，金银的汇率约为1：10，四

百两黄金约可换成四千两白银。（第十回）

5、吴应熊委托他打点关系，给了十万两银票，被他“先来个二一添作五”，暗中抽走了五万两。（第十

二回）

6、康亲王为答谢韦小宝帮偷经书，送了他一栋豪宅。（第二十九回）

7、当上“赐婚使”，收吴应熊贿赂：二十万两银票。（第三十回）

8、施琅为得清廷重用，向他行贿：一只白玉碗；一只六七两重的金饭碗，换成银子，约六七十两。

（第三十四回）

9、衣锦还乡，“沿途官员迎送，贿赂从丰。韦小宝自然来者不拒，迤逦南下，行李日重”。却不知到底

收到了多少银子。（第三十九回）

10、在台湾大征“请命费”，索贿一百万两银子。

施琅另送他“一份重礼”。（第四十六回）

11、勒索郑克塽：一百三十三万四千三百两银子。（第四十九回）

12、追讨郑克塽旧欠：一万多两银子。（第五十回）

合计一下，不计零头，韦小宝的贪污数字至少有300万两白银。而宝马、豪宅、翡翠、珍珠、白玉等难

以估值的财物，以及具体数目不明的礼金（如南归沿途官员的贿赂；施琅的“一份重礼”），尚未计算

在内，如果计算在内，恐怕数字要翻一番。

韦小宝贪了36亿

那么，假如将韦大人贪来的300万两银子折算成人民币，又值多少钱呢？

首先我需要建立一个换算的参照系。我们认为，以货币对大米的购买力进行换算，是一种比较合理、

靠谱的方法。

韦小宝生活在清代康熙朝前期，即17世纪下半叶。当时大清国的主要货币为白银与铜钱，银钱的汇率

约为1：1000，即1两银子可以兑换1000文钱。市场上大米的价格一般在每石300文~800文之间波动，

我们取其中间值，以每石500文钱计算（这个数值也便于折算）。清代的一石米约等于今天的150斤。

而现在商场中一斤普通的大米，大概要卖4块钱。这几个关键数目字弄清楚之后，我们便可以建立一个

大体上有效的换算等式：

1两银子=1000文钱=2石米=300斤米=1200元。（只对清代康熙前期有效）

根据这条等式，韦小宝腐败清单上的300万两银，换算过来，大约值36亿元人民币。辣块妈妈的，这

个“韦老虎”，单就账目一清二楚的银子，折算成人民币，就有36亿元之多。

我们还可以换一个参照系来估算：以人均国民收入为参照。

我未能找到清代康熙时期的人均国民收入数据，不过，在香港科技大学刘光临教授的论文中，找到乾

隆三十五年（1770年）的人均实际国民收入，为6.45两白银。康熙时期的人均国民收入应该略低于乾

隆时期，不过我们这里还是借用乾隆三十五年的数据来计算：韦小宝的贪污数目（300万两银）大约是

人均国民收入的46万倍。

而按国家统计局公布的数据，2014年全国居民人均可支配收入为20167元。如果按“46万倍”的腐败“额

度”计算，则是92亿元。换言之，韦小宝在康熙时代贪了300万两银，其严重程度相当于在今天贪了92

亿元。

——这种折算的方法不是很合理，但可以显示出韦大人腐败的严重程度。

如果韦小宝当年被“打虎棒”打了下来，大清国的纪检部门大概会这么发文：

经查，韦小宝在担任尚膳司副总管太监、后宫太监总管、上书房行走、赏穿黄马褂御前侍卫副总管、

骁骑营正黄旗副都统、骁骑正黄旗都统、钦差大臣、赐婚使、抚远大将军期间，利用职务之便，大肆

索贿、受贿，数目巨大，情节严重。又生活作风腐化，同时与多名女性保持不正当关系，与有夫之妇

（苏荃）通奸，造成十分恶劣的影响。奉皇帝圣旨，开除韦小宝所有公职，剥夺所有爵号，并移交大

理寺、刑部起诉。。

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

20 OCTOBER

The Efficiency of the Profit Motive

The profit motive alone gives fulfillment through power over things.

fulfillment：n. 履行；实行；满足（感）

The only relevant and meaningful question is whether the profit motive is the socially most

efficient one of the available directions in which the drive for power can be channeled.

relevant：

紧密相关的；切题的

closely connected with the subject you are discussing or the situation you are thinking about

But we can say that of the channels available and known to us, the profit motive has a very high, if

not the highest, social efficiency.

All the other known forms in which the lust for power can be expressed offer satisfaction by giving

the ambitious man direct power and domination over his fellow men.

lust：

The profit motive alone gives fulfillment through power over things.

ACTION POINT:

Take a position: power over things is less dangerous socially than power over people.

Take a position：

Concept of the Corporation

20 OCTOBER

The Efficiency of the Profit Motive

The profit motive alone gives fulfillment through power over things.

The only relevant and meaningful question is whether the profit motive is

the socially most efficient one of the available directions in which the drive

for power can be channeled. But we can say that of the channels

available and known to us, the profit motive has a very high, if not the

high-est, social efficiency. All the other known forms in which the lust for

power can be expressed offer satisfaction by giving the ambitious man

direct power and domination over his fellow men. The profit motive alone

gives fulfillment through power over things.

ACTION POINT:

Take a position: power over things is less dangerous so-

cially than power over people.

Concept of the Corporation

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

重阳宫下的店小二：没人敢在我们店里惹事

我们有一个金庸群，群里大家都把昵称改成金庸笔下的人物，我的昵称是“重阳宫下的店小二”，因为

我觉得那个店小二是一个很有趣的人，而且非常自信和自豪。

在金庸笔下做店小二是很危险的，动不动就会被一个女生割掉舌头（阿紫），还动不动就被点了穴

道，充分展示着龙套的本色。

如果遇到慕容复和丁春秋的打斗，店小二也就只好身先士卒，躲在一边，如果躲的不好，就只好去领

盒饭了。

偶尔有几个话多爱表现的店小二，都要冒这生命危险，不知道什么时候，头上就多了一个拂尘。

可是，我们那么重阳宫下的店小二就不一样了。他的胆子非常大的，而且理直气壮地大。

咱们来看看这位店小二，只见那店伴：

大逞雄辩，口舌便给，滔滔不绝，只驳得姬皮二道哑口无言。这店伴生性最爱与人斗口，平素没事尚

要撩拨旁人，何况此时有人惹上头来，更何况他是全然的理直气壮。只说得口沫横飞，精神越来越

旺。姬皮二道老羞成怒，欲待动手，但想到教中清规，此处是终南山脚下，怎敢胡来？只得忍气吞

声，关门而睡。那店伴兀自在房外唠叨不休。

然后呢，这个店小二是不是精神不正常呢？是不是拼上一身剐呢？店小二自己说了理由：

次日清晨，杨过起来吃面，那多嘴店伴过来招呼，口中喃喃不绝的还在骂人。杨过笑问：“那两个贼道

怎么啦？”店伴得意洋洋，说道：“直娘贼，这两个臭道士想吃白食丶住白店，本来瞧在重阳宫的份

上，那也不相干，可是他们竟敢说我们开黑店。今儿天没亮，两个贼道就溜走了。哼，老子定要告上

重阳宫去，全真教的道爷成千成万，那一个不是严守清规戒律？这两个贼道的贼相我可记得清清楚

楚，定要认了他们出来……”杨过暗暗好笑，又挑拨了几句

原来如此。

原来店小二有重阳宫撑腰。

这是个很有趣的话题，是什么让店小二有了这个想法呢？原来是重阳宫的“多管闲事”。

随着全真教势力和能力的提高，全真教不但可以给自己的弟子以庇护，还可以给重阳宫附近的普通百

姓以庇护。而全真教的目的，明显是为了给整个江湖的普通百姓以庇护，让他们可以不再畏惧武林人

士的武力威胁。

而这个，是店小二们最大的诉求。

不过我们如何关注那些绝顶高手，如何关注那些震惊天下的各种江湖大事，江湖上大部分人还是普通

人，而我们这些普通人，关心的只是工作用不要有意外，可以放松一些，不要动不动脑袋上就来一

掌，或者被扔到桥下。

为了实现这个目标，我们普通人愿意让渡一部分权力给某一个机构，让他来保护自己，我们愿意出让

部分金钱（税收），部分自由（留在指定的地方，比如重阳宫附近）来获得这个保护。

这就是我们的政府。

随着我们的诉求增多，比如，我期待我不能工作时也可以有一些收入，我期待我的儿子生病时可以有

人照顾，我期待我自己老了后可以有人照顾 ，我期待我睡着后，有人保护我不被打扰，而不用去学那

么多艰深的武功。

我们让渡的权力也越来越多，我会交更多的税，我会失去更多的自由。我必须在我健康时更多地工

作。

而政府，在获得越来越多的人让渡越来越多的权力后，终于成为了一个超级权力集合体，在这个集合

体面前，降龙十八掌不再有用，九阴真经也没啥意思了。凝血神爪？你在开玩笑么？

任何个人，不管武功多么厉害，在这个庞大的权力集合体面前都不值一提。

再后来，武功就消失了，因为，江湖进入了普通人的时代。

在《鹿鼎记》的最后，赫赫有名的冯锡范，被几个几乎没有武功的侍卫带走后，居然打个半死，自己

也不敢丝毫的还击。只是因为，那几个侍卫代表的是无数普通人让渡的权力。

最后，冯锡范死了，而无数个店小二在口若悬河，滔滔不绝。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

21 OCTOBER

The Megastate

Megastate：

Government ceased to be the rule setter, the facilitator, the insurer,the disbursement agent.

ceased：

停止 不再 做某事

facilitator：

V-T If you cease to do something, you stop doing it.

do

诱导者

;

(

)

a person who helps sb do sth more easily by discussing problems, giving advice, etc. rather than telling them what to

insurer：

disbursement：n. 支出，支付

a person or company that provides people with insurance

It became the doer and the manager.

doer：

承保人；保险公司

( approving ) a person who does things rather than thinking or talking about them

实干的人；身体力行者；实行者

While the nation-state was the sole political reality in the centuries of empires and superstates,

it has transformed itself profoundly in the last hundred years.

sole：

仅有的；唯一的

empires：

centuries：

superstates：

由几个国家组成的政

only; single

治)超级联盟

N-COUNT A superstate is a group of several countries that are very closely linked politically. (

transformed：

V-T To transform something into something else means to change or convert it into that thing.

使改变; 使转换

It mutated into the Megastate.

mutated：

V-T/V-I If an animal or plant mutates, or something mutates it, it develops different characteristics as the result of a

change in its genes.

使 (遗传基因等) 突变; 经受突变

The shift from the national state to the Megastate began in the last decades of the nineteenth

century.

The first small step toward the Megastate was German chancellor Bismarck’s invention in the

1880s of the Welfare State.

The other major social program of the period immediately after World War II, the British National

Health Service, was the first one (outside of the totalitarian countries) to take government beyond

the role of insurer or provider.

Hospitals and hospital care under the National Health Service were taken over by government.

The people working in hospitals became government employees; and government actually

manages the hospitals.

By 1960, it had become accepted doctrine in all developed Western countries that government is

the appropriate agent for all social problems and all social tasks.

doctrine：

教义；主义；学说；信条

appropriate：

美

‑

合适的；恰

[ C U ] a belief or set of beliefs held and taught by a Church, a political party, etc.

当的

/əˈprəʊpriət/

/əˈproʊ / ~ (for/to sth) suitable, acceptable or correct for the particular circumstances

And this held until the 1990s.

held：v. 握住（hold的过去分词）；举起,抬起；使升高；展示；提出(作为榜样)(后与as连用)

ACTION POINT:

Use the Internet to check out the service level provided by the British National Health Service.

Based upon this example and others which you are aware of, form an opinion as to the

effectiveness of gov-ernment as a provider of health services versus nonprofit and for-profit

entities.

Post-Capitalist Society

21 OCTOBER

The Megastate

Government ceased to be the rule setter, the facilitator, the insurer,

the disbursement agent. It became the doer and the manager.

While the nation-state was the sole political reality in the centuries of

empires and superstates, it has transformed itself profoundly in the last

hundred years. It mutated into the Megastate. The shift from the na-

tional state to the Megastate began in the last decades of the nineteenth

century. The first small step toward the Megastate was German chancellor

Bismarck’s invention in the 1880s of the Welfare State. The other major

social program of the period immediately after World War II, the British

National Health Service, was the first one (outside of the totalitarian

coun-tries) to take government beyond the role of insurer or provider.

Hospitals and hospital care under the National Health Service were taken

over by government. The people working in hospitals became

government em-ployees; and government actually manages the hospitals.

By 1960, it had become accepted doctrine in all developed Western

countries that government is the appropriate agent for all social problems

and all social tasks. And this held until the 1990s.

ACTION POINT:

Use the Internet to check out the service level provided by

the British National Health Service. Based upon this example and oth-ers

which you are aware of, form an opinion as to the effectiveness of gov-

ernment as a provider of health services versus nonprofit and for-profit

entities.

Post-Capitalist Society

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

可怜的张无忌 | 张无忌的一天

张无忌是《倚天屠龙记》的男主人公，这是一个很厉害的人物。不过，大家都不喜欢他。

女生不喜欢他，因为他磨磨唧唧，对感情也暧昧不清；男人也不喜欢，因为，在这样一个人面前，自

己是完全没有存在感的。

因为张无忌太强大了。

首先，张无忌是个武术高手，乾坤大挪移，九阳神功，太极拳、太极剑。每一个武功，别人一辈子都

入不了门，他却短时间到了顶峰。环顾整个江湖，真看不出谁可以接的住他一拳，或者一掌。

哪怕是一堆敌人一起打过来，只要他出手，一个人可以对抗一支军队。

其次，他还是个大夫，也就是医生 。他跟着蝶谷医仙胡青牛学习了医术。胡青牛死后，他已经是当世

第一了。不管什么病，到了他那里都是小儿科。三伯俞岱岩残疾几十年了，也被他治的可以自己行走

了。

至于那些稀奇古怪的病，更是手到病除。你看，青翼蝠王韦一笑一辈子都搞不定的练功就要吸血问

题，他一下就给解决了。

而且，张无忌还有浩如大海的内功，在金庸的设定里，内功是个神奇的东西，可阴可阳。可以治愈百

病，也可以抵御各种蛊毒。在九阳神功的加持下，张无忌几成不死之身的同时，可以随时无限地帮助

身边的任何人。

韦一笑，殷离等，随便拿张无忌一点内力，就可以改变人生。

仿佛，只要有张无忌这个人在，其他人就都不用做事了。

玄冥二老来了？无忌，去，打他一掌；

他师父受伤了？无忌，来，给大师父输点内力；

什么?舅舅和人打架头被打破了？无忌，快去，给你舅舅包扎一下。

是呀，在张无忌面前，整个世界变成了张无忌和他们小伙伴们。张无忌负责了所有的事情：打架，防

病，治病，这些江湖人常见的三大事情。其他人呢？帮助张无忌就好了，把自己当成张无忌的左膀右

臂。

无忌要去打架了，帮他看看路，小昭，看一下无忌的干粮带了么？阿离，无忌换洗的衣服带了么？天

冷了，多带两套。

舅老爷几天没吃饭了，无忌也来看看吧。

无忌，无忌，哪里都是无忌。好像离了无忌就不行了。而无忌也确实把所有的事情都做了。

这时突然来了一个人，这个人对张无忌说：“教主，我知道您很厉害，您能帮我一个忙么？”

张无忌刚给一个村妇接生回来，路上又劝了一对要离婚的夫妻。看着这个年龄比自己还大的下属，张

无忌说：“什么事呀，说吧，我肯定能搞定”。

这个人说道：“我想请您消失”

“因为，没有您，对未来的国家很重要。”

这个人叫做朱元璋。

故事之外：

前几天和朋友聊天，聊到一个公司，公司的老板很忙。在一次和他们老板一起吃饭时，他的助理在边

上不断提醒他的时间表：14：00做什么，14：30做什么，14：50做什么。

到了公司后，发现公司的很多人都在等着向他汇报。

这个公司不大，有几十个人，里面有一些水平不错的人。大家各自负责一块，最后由这个老板来定

夺。

我和这个朋友说，这个公司其实并不能算一个公司，只能算一个个人加一群助理而已。

我朋友惊讶地说：“不是呀，他们工资很高的”

我说，这和工资没关系，那也只说明他们只是一个高工资的助理而已，因为他们不对事情负责，只是

对老板负责。

我想，这样的公司，需要一个朱元璋这样的人，对这位老板说：“没有您对我们很重要”。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

22 OCTOBER

Purpose of Government

Every government is a “government of forms.”

Government is a poor manager.

It is, of necessity, concerned with procedure, and it is also, of necessity, large and cumbersome.

cumbersome：

大而笨重的；难以携带的

large and heavy; difficult to carry

Government is also properly conscious of the fact that it administers public funds and must

account for every penny.

conscious：

意识到；注意到

penny：

￡ 便士（英国的小硬币和货币单

[ not before noun ] ~ of (doing) sth | ~ that aware of sth; noticing sth

(abbr. p ) a small British coin and unit of money. There are 100 pence in one pound (

位，1英镑为100便士）

1).

It has no choice but to be “bureaucratic.”

bureaucratic：（

often disapproving ) connected with a bureaucracy or bureaucrats and involving complicated official rules

which may seem unnecessary

官僚的；官僚主义的

Whether government is a “government of laws” or a “government of men” is debatable.

debatable：

可争辩的；有争议

的

not certain because people can have different ideas and opinions about the thing being discussed

But every government is, by definition, a “government of forms.”

This means inevitably high costs.

inevitably：

不可避免地；必然地

as is certain to happen

But, the purpose of government is to make fundamental decisions, and to make them effectively.

fundamental：

十分重大的；根本的

serious and very important; affecting the most central and important parts of sth

The purpose of government is to focus the political energies of society.

It is to dramatize issues. It is to present fundamental choices.

dramatize：

将 改编成剧本；将 搬上（舞台或银幕）

[ VN ] to present a book, an event, etc. as a play or a film/movie

…

…

The purpose of government, in other words, is to govern.

govern：

to legally control a country or its people and be responsible for introducing new laws, organizing public services, etc.

治；控制；管理；治理

This, as we have learned, in other institutions, is incompatible with “doing.”

统

incompatible with：与…不适宜(不相称）

Any attempt to combine governing with “doing” on a large scale, paralyzes the decision-making

capacity.

paralyzes： 使麻痹；使瘫痪

Business has had to face, on a much smaller scale, the problem that modern government now

faces: the incompatibility between “governing” and “doing.”

Business management learned that the two have to be separated, and that the top organ, the

decision maker, has to be detached from “doing.”

organ：

（人

a part of the body that has a particular purpose, such as the heart or the brain; part of a plant with a particular purpose

体或动植物的）器官

Otherwise he does not make decisions, and the “doing” does not get done either.

In business this goes by the name of “decentralization.”

decentralization：n. 分散；非集权化；

ACTION POINT:

What are some clear examples of nonprofit organizations that are doing a better job addressing a

social problem than a government agency?

The Age of Discontinuity

22 OCTOBER

Purpose of Government

Every government is a “government of forms.”

Government is a poor manager. It is, of necessity, concerned with

pro-cedure, and it is also, of necessity, large and cumbersome. Govern-

ment is also properly conscious of the fact that it administers public funds

and must account for every penny. It has no choice but to be “bureau-

cratic.” Whether government is a “government of laws” or a “government

of men” is debatable. But every government is, by definition, a “govern-

ment of forms.” This means inevitably high costs.

But, the purpose of government is to make fundamental decisions, and

to make them effectively. The purpose of government is to focus the

politi-cal energies of society. It is to dramatize issues. It is to present

fundamental choices. The purpose of government, in other words, is to

govern. This, as we have learned, in other institutions, is incompatible

with “doing.” Any attempt to combine governing with “doing” on a large

scale, paralyzes the decision-making capacity. Business has had to face,

on a much smaller scale, the problem that modern government now faces:

the incompatibility between “governing” and “doing.” Business

management learned that the two have to be separated, and that the top

organ, the decision maker, has to be detached from “doing.” Otherwise he

does not make decisions, and the “doing” does not get done either. In

business this goes by the name of “de-centralization.”

ACTION POINT:

What are some clear examples of nonprofit organizations

that are doing a better job addressing a social problem than a government

agency?

The Age of Discontinuity

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

罗胖之死

罗胖在创业，像所有创业者一样，罗胖不怕辛苦，也不怕累，也不怕冒险。

找两个人，买个摄像机，买个录音笔，公司就开张了。业务也很简单：每天早上6点钟，罗胖用60秒的

语音陪你起床。

这是一个不大容易的事情，不过也不难。在那个时间点，罗胖做到了，加上个人的天赋，不经意间，

罗胖开创了一个领域：自媒体时代。

接着，罗胖的声音，还有理智，就成了罗胖公司的标签了，罗胖公司叫啥？不知道，我只知道罗胖。

再后来，罗胖开始做电商，有流量就做电商，是那个时代的共识，毕竟，电商的流量最直接的变现渠

道。现在罗胖的卖书还保留了当时电商的一些痕迹。

电商只是流量变现，产品不是自己做的，随着卖的东西越来越多，罗胖的名声也开始坏了起来。

罗胖陷入了一个不好的陷阱：流量 VS 现金？这种置换不合算呀。

罗胖开始简化自己的电商：只卖书。罗胖是个读书人，自己也读过不少书，而书是最容易标准化的。

为了让自己的流量换取跟多的现金，甚至越用越多，罗胖开始自己选书。

这就有了罗胖的“周五上新日”，每周推荐一本书，罗胖也就成了知识电商。

知识电商，让罗胖声名鹊起，罗胖在影响力也越来越大。每天只要有罗胖的声音，就不愁卖不出东西

了。就不愁没有现金流了。

这时的“罗胖的公司”，每天都围着罗胖转，大家知道，这个肥胖油腻的中年男人就是公司的摇钱树。

这时，脱不花来了，她说要杀死罗胖。

2017年，在六神磊磊的新书《六神磊磊读唐诗》新书发布会上，很久没有出现在公共场合的罗胖突然

现身了。

他自己说近三年来，自己没有参加过任何商业的和非商业的活动，这是第一次。我猜，这应该是为了

配合脱不花的“杀死罗胖”的计划。

在三年多了，罗胖的公司进行着痛苦的“去罗胖化”，在去罗胖化的同时，一大多的知识网红崛起。而

这些知识网红，构建了一个“得到”。

这是一个成功的转型。

这个世界不缺有知识的人，也不缺有才华的人。缺的是发现才华的能力，更是把这种才华有效传播的

能力。而这两种能力，罗胖在自己身上先做了实验（实践）。

接着，他们开始发掘其他有才华的人了。刘雪枫、和菜头、王煜全等第一批人入住，罗胖团队用自己

的经验让这批人得到了非常好的传播。

也得到非常好的收入。

这个“得到”说的大概是大家“得到”知识的同时，这些大咖“得到”真金白银吧。

然后，得到开始发布“品控手册”，这个品控手册是一个纲领性的东西，它一方面让用户了解得到对知

识的严肃程度，一方面也让有意于知识服务行业的人知道，原来做这个行业需要如此用心。

有了这个品控手册，虽然得到提高了知识服务行业的门槛，却得到更容易获得真正优秀的老师了。

我一个朋友，就一直想去得到录课，她觉得，赚钱还是次要的，那个过程会让自己收到一种类似专业

的磨练。

这时，知识付费市场上出现了一个新的职业：以公司的形式，或者团队的形式为得到提供课程内容，

如拆书等。

而这些公司，或者个人，或者团队，都以这个机会和能力为荣。

经过这几步后，得到在行业中的地位也就越来越稳定了，成为行业标准的制定者。而罗胖，这个“得

到”公司的创始人，谁还在意他？

这样一来，罗胖就死了，那个每天都要不停工作，支撑起整个公司的罗胖死了；却活过来一个叫做罗

振宇的人，那是一个父亲的儿子，那个几个孩子的爸爸。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

23 OCTOBER

Government Decentralization

Decentralization： 分散； 经管 非集权化；（人口、工业等的） 军 疏散

[

]

[ ]

dispersal, deconcentration

Reprivatization will restore strength and performance capacity to sick and incapacitated

government.

Reprivatization：n. 国营改民营，发还私营

incapacitated：

使 能力

变弱; 使伤残

V-T If something incapacitates you, it weakens you in some way, so that you cannot do certain things.

…

“Decentralization” applied to government would not be just another form of “federalism” in which

local rather than central government discharges the “doing” tasks.

federalism： 联邦制；联邦主义

discharges：

unionism

V-T When someone is discharged from a hospital, prison, or one of the armed services, they are officially allowed to

leave, or told that they must leave.

批准离开; 命令离开

It would rather be a systematic policy of using the other, the nongovernmental institutions of the

society of organizations,for the actual “doing,” that is, for performance, operations, execution.

systematic：

成体系的；系统的；有条理的；有计

划有步骤的

done according to a system or plan, in a thorough, efficient or determined way

Government would start out by asking the question: “How do these institutions work and what

can they do?” It would then ask: “How can political and social objectives be formulated and

organized in such a manner as to become opportunities for performance for these

institutions?”

start out:

以 做某事 开始

formulated:

构想出 计

PHRASAL VERB If you start out by doing something, you do it at the beginning of an activity.

(

)

V-T If you formulate something such as a plan or proposal, you invent it, thinking about the details carefully.

划或提案)

as to：至于，关于；就……而论

(

It would then ask: “And what opportunities for accomplishment of political objectives do the

abilities and capacities of these institutions offer to government?”

accomplishment ：

成就；成绩

[ C ] an impressive thing that is done or achieved after a lot of work

Reprivatization will not weaken government.

Indeed, its main purpose is to restore strength and performance capacity to sick and incapacitated

government.

We cannot go much further along the road on which government has been traveling.

traveling:

All we can get this way is more bureaucracy and not more performance.

bureaucracy:

[ U ] ( often disapproving ) the system of official rules and ways of doing things that a government or an organization

has, especially when these seem to be too complicated

ACTION POINT:

官僚主义；官僚作风

Draft a proposal to turn a social program into an opportunity for your organization or one you

might start.

proposal:

提议；建议；动议

[ C U ] ~ (for sth) | ~ (to do sth) | ~ (that…) a formal suggestion or plan; the act of making a suggestion

The Age of Discontinuity

23 OCTOBER

Government Decentralization

Reprivatization will restore strength and performance capacity to sick

and incapacitated government.

“Decentralization” applied to government would not be just another form

of “federalism” in which local rather than central government discharges the

“doing” tasks. It would rather be a systematic policy of using the other, the

nongovernmental institutions of the society of organizations,

for the actual “doing,” that is, for performance, operations, execution.

Government would start out by asking the question: “How do these in-

stitutions work and what can they do?” It would then ask: “How can

politi-cal and social objectives be formulated and organized in such

Amanner as to become opportunities for performance for these

institutions?” It would then ask: “And what opportunities for

accomplishment of political objec-tives do the abilities and capacities of

these institutions offer to govern-ment?” Reprivatization will not weaken

government. Indeed, its main purpose is to restore strength and

performance capacity to sick and inca-pacitated government. We cannot

go much further along the road on which government has been traveling.

All we can get this way is more bu-reaucracy and not more performance.

ACTION POINT:

Draft a proposal to turn a social program into an oppor-

tunity for your organization or one you might start.

The Age of Discontinuity

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

厉害了我的国

我爱我的祖国，因为我和我的祖国在一起，而且，一刻也不会分离。

而且，我的祖国也在变得越来也好，阳光越来也明媚，空气越来也好，男人也越来越帅气，女人也越

来越美丽，人们也越来越从容，生活也越来越自在。

比如，我们的龙队就有一个新发现，他发现，居然可以躺在家里借书，然后就用人把书送达家，而这

一切，都是免费的。

后来，我也发现，在我家门口也开了一家书店，很大，很宽敞，还很漂亮。

（放入通州店的图片）

我走进这件书店，发现这家书店很有特色，居然是一家图书馆主题的书店。没听懂？就是说，这个书

店可以免费借阅图书馆的书，以及新书，也可以还图书馆的书。

而且，书店里可以喝咖啡，还有懒人沙发。我可以葳蕤地待一天。或者看书，或者不看书。

书店里的人不多，和就和店长聊了会天，店长说，书店在商业化下，带有公益性质，目的还是给社区

的人提供阅读的场所和书籍。

这个书店叫做更读书社。目前在大兴，通州和隆福寺各有一个，都是在700平米左右。

更读书社还运营了一些24小时书房，大约有二十多个。24小时书房是一个很有趣的存在，他们大多在

小区附近，采用人脸识别技术，或者刷卡技术。24小时，同学们随时可以通过北京除国图外的任何图

书馆卡进入。

你可以在里面阅读、借阅、还书。

2018年1月1日，国家的《公共图书馆法》正式生效，按《公共图书馆法》

第十三条：国家建立覆盖城乡、便捷实用的公共图书馆服务网络。公共图书馆服务网络建设坚持政府

主导，鼓励社会参与。

县级以上地方人民政府应当根据本行政区域内人口数量、人口分布、环境和交通条件等因素，因地制

宜确定公共图书馆的数量、规模、结构和分布，加强固定馆舍和流动服务设施、自助服务设施建设。

网上经常有人发一些很励志的帖子，说中国人读书如何如何少，犹太人读书如何如何多，说欧洲人在

地铁上都是看说，而我们都是看手机，如此云云。

不管我们说多少这样的话，也改变不了我们的阅读习惯。而这个图书馆法却在悄悄改变着什么。

去多了更读书社后，也认识了几个他们的运营人员。了解到他们的部分场地是政府买单的，这样一

来，他们的运营成本就低了很多，优雅的场地，也吸引更多的人愿意经常来休息，阅读，以及参加书

店里的各种活动。他们的咖啡也就卖的不错了。（客观来说，他们的咖啡确实不错。）

运营一个书店，最大的成本肯定是房租成本，这一部分成本由政府承当了一部分后，让书店运营的难

度就降低了很多，也让更多有情怀的人愿意去启动一个书店，运营一个书店。

在你身边，这样的书店，书房越来越多，你看书的可能性也就越来越多。

创赢读书会的发起人，陈开元老师曾经说过：“我做这个读书会，首先是因为我个人自己要读书，其

次，我希望把一些中年人从牌桌拉到书桌上来。”

是呀，我们读书少，只是五抱怨是没有什么用的。

从政府的角度，他们会出台一些法律；相光的地方政府根据法律，出台一些对应的政策，而做为有商

业敏感性，又有情怀的一些人，如更读书社的老板，他们就会借助法律的支持，结合各地落实政策的

特点，成立这种让你流连忘返的书店。

是呀，我不一定读书，也不一定不读书。在我空闲时，我走出家门，随意走进一个书店，看着各种书

籍，看着各种阅读的人，看着各种碰撞的思想。我想，一切都在悄悄的变化。

我爱我的祖国，因为我看到了这一点点的变化。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

24 OCTOBER

Strong Government

Government would be the “conductor” who tries to think through what each instrument is best

designed to do.

conductor：

a person who stands in front of an orchestra , a group of singers etc., and directs their performance, especially sb

who does this as a profession

（管弦乐队、合唱队等的）指挥；职业指挥

We do not face a “withering away of the state,” as Karl Marx promised.

withering：

神情、话语等

尖刻的；使人难堪的；令人无地自容

的

( of a look, remark, etc.

) intended to make sb feel silly or ashamed

On the contrary, we need a vigorous, a strong, and a very active government.

vigorous：

充满活力的；果断的；精力充沛的

very active, determined or full of energy

But we do face a choice between big and impotent government and a government that is strong

because it confines itself to decision and direction and leaves the “doing” to others.

impotent：

无能为力的；不起作用的

having no power to change things or to influence a situation

confines：vt. 限制；禁闭（confine的三单形式）

We do not face a “return of laissez-faire” in which the economy is left alone.

laissez-faire：

[ U ] ( from French ) the policy of allowing private businesses to develop without government control

商业的）自由放任政策

（政府对私有

In all major areas we have a new choice in this pluralist society of organizations: an organic

diversity in which institutions are used to do what they are best equipped to do.

pluralist：

社会

多元性的；多元化的

organic：

食品、耕作方式等

有机的；不使

( of a society

) having many different groups of people and different political parties in it

( of food, farming methods, etc.

) produced or practised without using artificial chemicals

用化肥的；绿色的

diversity：[ U ] [ C usually sing. ] a range of many people or things that are very different from each other 差异（性）；不同（点）

Government would figure out how to structure a given political objective so as to make it

attractive to one of the autonomous institutions.

And just as we praise a composer for his ability to write “playable” music, which best uses the

specific performance characteristic of French horn, violin, or flute, we may come to praise the

lawmaker who best structures a particular task so as to make it most congenial for this or that of

the autonomous, self-governing, private institutions of pluralist society.

congenial：

人

意气相投

( of a person

) pleasant to spend time with because their interests and character are similar to your own

的；情趣相投的；合得来的

autonomous：( of a country, a region or an organization 国家、地区、组织 ) able to govern itself or control its own affairs 自治

的；有自治权的

ACTION POINT: Write a letter to an editor praising a lawmaker who structures government

programs to be managed by nongovernmental institutions and to have the ability to solve social

problems where government programs are deficient.

The Age of Discontinuity

24 OCTOBER

Strong Government

Government would be the “conductor” who tries to think through

what each instrument is best designed to do.

We do not face a “withering away of the state,” as Karl Marx promised.

On the contrary, we need a vigorous, a strong, and a very active gov-ernment.

But we do face a choice between big and impotent government and

Agovernment that is strong because it confines itself to decision and di-rection

and leaves the “doing” to others. We do not face a “return of laissez-faire” in

which the economy is left alone. In all major areas we have a new choice in

this pluralist society of organizations: an organic diversity in

which institutions are used to do what they are best equipped to do.

Government would figure out how to structure a given political objec-

tive so as to make it attractive to one of the autonomous institutions. And

just as we praise a composer for his ability to write “playable” music,

which best uses the specific performance characteristic of French horn,

violin, or flute, we may come to praise the lawmaker who best structures

a particular task so as to make it most congenial for this or that of the

autonomous, self-governing, private institutions of pluralist society.

ACTION POINT:

Write a letter to an editor praising a lawmaker who struc-

tures government programs to be managed by nongovernmental institu-

tions and to have the ability to solve social problems where government

programs are deficient.

The Age of Discontinuity

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

方证的故事

说起笑傲江湖，里面的人物大家都耳熟能详。里面的很多人物已经印在了大家的心理，比如，提到伪

君子，自然就是岳不群。

笑傲江湖讲的是一群颇有野心的人不断谋划一统江湖，最后，反而是一个一点野心都没有的人笑道了

最后。

说道有野心的人，笑傲江湖是还是挺多的。在这部小说里，不管是正派，还是邪教，都有大量有野心

的人，比如魔教的东方不败，任我行，比如正派的左冷禅，岳不群，还有不入流的，如余沧海等。

里面有正派的人物么？令狐冲当然算，莫大可能也算一个，还有就是方证、方生和武当的冲虚道长

了。这些人抵御着来自任我行、左冷禅还有岳不群的一统江湖、努力武林人士的梦想。

问题是，方证真的是正面人物么？

笑傲江湖里，有一统武林梦想的人，真的只有东方不败，任我行，左冷禅，岳不群这几个人么？今天

咱们聊聊方证，这个大和尚。

方证是少林派的掌门人，少林是武林公认的第一大派。少林的方丈也就是很有地位的人了。

在当时的武林，正派有少林、武当、五岳派等，邪派有魔教，还有很多大大小小的门派亦正亦邪。而

这些所有的门派公认少林为武林领袖。

不过，武林么，肯定是以武力为最大考虑，当任我行有了武力有，他就想当武林盟主了。没想几天，

他就被他的副手，东方不败给关了起来。

接受任我行地盘和权力的东方不败也想当武林盟主。他努力练武，想当武林第一人，进而武林盟主。

可是，割了鸡鸡后的东方不败，突然野心也被割掉了。开始关注自我的感受，不大在江湖留意了。反

而是他的情人热衷于权力。

不过，热衷于权力的情人能力和想象力都有点欠缺，也就没有做出什么大事来。

接下来就是左冷禅了，左冷禅成为五岳派盟主后，开始谋划并派，希望自己成为一个前所未有的大

派：五岳派的创始人。

这些就是方证面对的江湖，方证知道，这个江湖很险恶。方证想，我才是这个江湖的盟主呀，凭什么

有加一个盟主？那我去干去？捡垃圾么？

当岳不群把令狐冲逐出华山派后，当方生告诉他说令狐冲是风清扬的传人后，当他知道令狐冲和魔教

有千丝万缕的联系后，方证做出了第一个判断：收服令狐冲。

是呀，令狐冲是一个多么合适而又单纯的年轻人呀。

方证决定收令狐冲为弟子，这样一来，自己就和这个年轻人绑定在了一起。

没想到这个年轻人居然拒绝了。好吧。只好继续等机会。

后来，恒山派的定闲、定逸师太死在少林寺，临死前，定闲师太遗命令狐冲为恒山掌门人。方证一

看，又来机会了。就借着令狐冲就任时，亲自去恒山观礼，顺便和令狐冲商量破坏五岳派合并的事

情。

五岳派合并，必然在正派出现一个不次于少林的武术力量。在武林中，这是对少林的直接挑衅。方证

肯定不能接受。

方证拉上冲虚和令狐冲商量半天，终于说服了令狐冲去抢五岳派盟主。方证知道，他并没有明确的道

理来阻止五岳派的合并，只好让令狐冲来捣乱。

在五岳派合并大会上，也有人提议方证出任五岳派的掌门人，不过，被左冷禅一带而过。方证也摇摇

头一带而过。

令所有人意外的是，岳不群成为了五岳派的掌门人。以方证对岳不群的了解，方证知道岳不群也是有

野心的。也会对少林的领头羊地位造成威胁。

方证对岳不群表示愿意派出武力和岳不群共同防护嵩山。机智的岳不群拒绝了。

再后来，令狐冲和左冷禅、岳不群等火拼，左冷禅和岳不群等都死掉了，而任我行则向恒山挑战。这

时的恒山已经是五岳派仅存的力量了。方证知道，如果恒山派再完蛋了，少林和武当就要直接面临魔

教的威胁。

所以，方证决定用一些阴谋手段帮助令狐冲对抗魔教，在恒山上来一个大决战。

好在，任我行死了，任盈盈接任魔教教主后，和令狐冲相安无事。

再后来，令狐冲把掌门之位传给了仪清，任盈盈把教主之位传给了向问天。各大派有野心的人都死掉

了。方证也就踏实了。

继续维持着天下第一大派的身份和地位。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

25 OCTOBER

Government in the International Sphere

Sphere：

an area of activity, influence or interest; a particular section of society

范围；领域；阶层；界

Environmental protection might well be the most productive purpose of foreign aid.

We need strong, effective governments in the international sphere so that we can make the

sacrifices of sovereignty needed to give us working supranational institutions for the world

society and world economy.

sacrifices：

献祭

sovereignty：

主权；最高统治权；最高权威

supranational：

超国家的（指涉及不止一个国家）

institutions：

V-T To sacrifice an animal or person means to kill them in a special religious ceremony as an offering to a god.

(over sth) complete power to govern a country

( formal ) involving more than one country

N-COUNT/N-IN-NAMES An institution is a building where certain people are cared for, such as people who are

mentally ill or children who have no parents.

社会福利机构

Protection of the environment today requires international ecological laws.

We might “quarantine” polluters and forbid shipment in international commerce of goods

produced under conditions that seriously pollute or damage the human habitat—for example, by

polluting the oceans, by raising the temperature of the atmosphere, or by depleting its ozone.

quarantine：

[ U ] a period of time when an animal or a person that has or may have a disease is kept away from others in order

to prevent the disease from spreading

polluter：

habitat：

depleting：

ozone：

（为防传染的）隔离期；检疫

a person, company, country, etc. that causes pollution

污染源；污染者

[ C U ] the place where a particular type of animal or plant is normally found

（动植物的）生活环境，栖息地

消耗

( chemistry 化 ) a poisonous gas with a strong smell that is a form of oxygen 臭氧

V-T To deplete a stock or amount of something means to reduce it.

This will be decried as “interference with sovereign nations”—and so it is.

interference：

干涉；干预；介入

sovereign：

国家

(in sth) the act of interfering

[ only before noun ] ( of a country or state

) free to govern itself; completely independent

有主权的；完全独立的

It will probably require that the developed rich countries compensate the developing poor ones for

the high costs of environmental protection, such as sewage treatment plants.

compensate：

补偿；弥补

sewage：

[ V ] ~ (for sth) to provide sth good to balance or reduce the bad effects of damage, loss, etc.

[ U ] used water and waste substances that are produced by human bodies, that are carried away from houses and

factories through special pipes (= sewers )

（下水道的）污水，污物

In fact, environmental protection might well be the most productive purpose of foreign aid and far

more successful than development aid.

productive：

doing or achieving a lot

有效益的；富有成效的

ACTION POINT: Support the use of foreign aid to protect the environment.

The Age of Discontinuity

The New Realities

25 OCTOBER

Government in the International Sphere

Environmental protection might well be the most

productive purpose of foreign aid.

We need strong, effective governments in the international sphere so that

we can make the sacrifices of sovereignty needed to give us working

supranational institutions for the world society and world

economy.

Protection of the environment today requires international ecological

laws. We might “quarantine” polluters and forbid shipment in interna-

tional commerce of goods produced under conditions that seriously pol-

lute or damage the human habitat—for example, by polluting the oceans,

by raising the temperature of the atmosphere, or by depleting its ozone.

This will be decried as “interference with sovereign nations”—and so it

is. It will probably require that the developed rich countries compensate

the developing poor ones for the high costs of environmental protection,

such as sewage treatment plants. In fact, environmental protection might

well be the most productive purpose of foreign aid and far more

successful than development aid.

ACTION POINT:

Support the use of foreign aid to protect the environ-ment.

The Age of Discontinuity

The New Realities

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

油门，刹车和司机

作为一个老司机，我知道，一辆车必须有个油门，也必须有个刹车，至于司机，则是可有可无。

油门是用来加油的，也就是提速的，车的目的，总是去向远方，不然要车干嘛。当你想去某个远方

时，你就需要轻轻踩一下油门，车就动了起来，随着车的速度慢慢加起来，你也会不断加踩油门，然

后，你和你的车就上路了。

在路上，你需要经常踩油门，因为，公路是有摩擦的，如果你不踩油门，车慢慢就会慢下来，然后停

下来，停下来或者慢下来的车，不能把你送到目的地。

同时，我们还需要刹车，因为路并不是直的，很少有一条路直直的，而且路上也没有车的情况，我们

需要转弯，需要避让其他的车辆，所以，我们也经常需要减速后调整角度，或者减速后等其他车错

车。

当然，我们不减速也可以转弯，只是有可能会翻车，翻车就有可能车毁人亡。虽然弯路超车很刺激。

遇到其他车当然也可以不减速，因为其他车也会减速，凭什么让我减速。只是这样一来就会增大撞车

的危险，一样会车毁人亡。

我们还需要一个方向盘，用来调整方向。有一次在我在内蒙开车，一条直路，没有弯道，连续几十公

里我都没有动方向盘。不过，我的手还是会放在方向盘上。

虽然说没动，其实还是动了。因为双手还是会微调，轻微地转过来，转过去，只是为了保持手感和手

对方向盘力量的感觉。

油门在提速，刹车在减速，方向盘在调整方向。在这三位一体的作用下，我会安全达到目的地。前提

是不要出意外，路上不要出现那种没有带刹车的车， 也没有哪种没有按方向盘的车。

没踩一脚油门，我们都会消耗一些油，这些油会把我们推的离目的地近一些，每踩一脚刹车，我们也

会消耗一些油，而这些油会让我们离目的地远一些。这就是油门和刹车的功用。

我们不能因为只想以最快的目的到达目的地，就只要油门不要刹车。因为这样太危险了，你不能保证

在路上不会遇到其他的车，而且不能保证你的车头正对着正确的方向，而且一路都是直的，没有任何

转弯。

更不能给驾驶员按一条铁腿，让他在需要的时候把腿伸出去用来刹车，这样一来，我们的驾驶员白白

牺牲一条腿不说，我们的车还是很危险。

我们的高速上有一些设置是用来让那种失去刹车功能的车减速的。这说明，我们是知道，也认可车是

需要有减速功能的。而且，失去的减速功能的车是危险的。

毕竟，我们的目的是平安到达，而不是到达。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

26 OCTOBER

Needed: Strong Labor Unions

To become again a dynamic, effective, legitimate organ, the labor union will have to transform

itself.

dynamic：

人

充满活力的；精力充沛的；个性强的

legitimate：

合法的；法律认可的；法定的

organ：

（官方的）机构，机关

( approving ) ( of a person

) having a lot of energy and a strong personality

allowed and acceptable according to the law

( formal ) an official organization that is part of a larger organization and has a special purpose

The true strength of the labor movement in developed countries has been moral: its claim to be

the political conscience of a modern secular society.

moral：

道德的

conscience：

凭良心

secular：

现世的；世俗的；非宗教的

[ only before noun ] concerned with principles of right and wrong behaviour

[ U ] the fact of behaving in a way that you feel is right even though this may cause problems

not connected with spiritual or religious matters

Management—no matter who “owns” and no matter whether the institution is a business, a

government agency, or a hospital—has to have considerable power and authority—power and

authority grounded in the needs of the enterprise and based on competence.

enterprise：

（尤指艰巨而重大的）规划，事业

competence：

律

（法庭、机构或人的）权

[ C ] a large project, especially one that is difficult SYN venture

[ U ] ( law

限，管辖权

) the power that a court, an organization or a person has to deal with sth

And power, as the drafters of the American Constitution knew, needs to be limited by

countervailing power.

drafters：

（计划、文件等的）起草人，拟稿者

Constitution：

宪法；章程

countervailing：

抗衡的；抵消的

a person who prepares a rough version of a plan, document, etc.

[ C ] the system of laws and basic principles that a state, a country or an organization is governed by

[ only before noun ] ( formal ) having an equal but opposite effect

Modern society, a society of organizations each requiring strong management, needs an

organ such as the labor union.

In the last few years events have amply proved this.

But to become again a dynamic, effective, legitimate organ, the labor union will have to transform

itself drastically.

drastically： 彻底地；激烈地

thoroughly, entirely, completely, fully, strongly

Otherwise the union will become irrelevant.

irrelevant：

(to sth/sb) not important to or connected with a situation

无关紧要的；不相关的

ACTION POINT:

Reflect on constructive ways labor unions can check the power of businesses, governments, and

hospitals.

Reflect:

constructive:

建设性的；有助益的；积极的

having a useful and helpful effect rather than being negative or with no purpose

The Frontiers of Management

26 OCTOBER

Needed: Strong Labor Unions

To become again a dynamic, effective, legitimate organ,

the labor union will have to transform itself.

The true strength of the labor movement in developed countries has been moral:

its claim to be the political conscience of a modern secu-

lar society.

Management—no matter who “owns” and no matter whether the insti-

tution is a business, a government agency, or a hospital—has to have con-

siderable power and authority—power and authority grounded in the

needs of the enterprise and based on competence. And power, as the

drafters of the American Constitution knew, needs to be limited by coun-

tervailing power. Modern society, a society of organizations each

requiring strong management, needs an organ such as the labor union. In

the last few years events have amply proved this. But to become again

Adynamic, ef-fective, legitimate organ, the labor union will have to

transform itself dras-tically. Otherwise the union will become irrelevant.

ACTION POINT:

Reflect on constructive ways labor unions can check the

power of businesses, governments, and hospitals.

The Frontiers of Management

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

你是知识工人？还是有知识的无产者？

德鲁克定义了一个新的群体：知识工人。德鲁克认为，这是现代社会的一个主要群体。他既不是农

民，也不是工人，当然，更不是地主。德鲁克认为，他们其实是“资本家”。

对，他们是新型的“资本家”。

顾名思义，资本家是靠资本来生存的。也就是说，你的生存的资料，如钱，物等，来自于资本，而不

是你的劳力，体力或者知识。

为什么这么说呢？这和知识工人的特征有关系。

知识工人对组织的重要性是比较高的，所以，组织，也就是企业会做比较多的事情来吸引知识工人，

知识工人也就有了比较多的自主权。

在传统理解上，企业是企业主对雇员的压迫和剥削，企业主依靠压榨雇员的剩余价值来生活。到了知

识工人时代，每一个知识工人都有一定的不可取代性。企业为了发展，需要给知识工人提供良好的工

作环境，以及退休的保障。

这里有一个很重要的制度，就是养老金制度，比如美国的401K养老计划，通过这个计划，雇员、雇主

共同缴费建立起来的完全基金式的养老保险制度，比知识工人可以将自己收入的一部分，连同企业按

比例配置的金额投入到自己喜欢的证券组合投资计划之中。

知识工人通过这个“企业年金”可以有一个稳定而富足的老年。在这个层面上，知识工人相当于企业的

“股东”。也就成资本家了。

知识工人通过自己的知识赚钱，然后通过赚的钱去生活（用于现在），购买401K基金（用于未来）。

他们可能会离开某一个公司，然后又去另一个公司上班，这个只是“跳槽”。但他们的两部分钱（用于

现在的，和用于未来的）都没有变化。

知识工人们当然有老板，他们也有下属，不过，他们应该没有被剥削的概念，毕竟，通过养老金计划

（国家层面的和企业层面的），这个企业，甚至整个社会的进步，他们都可以享受到。

德鲁克认为，知识工人不再是工人阶级，当然也不是企业家，他把这群人定义为“uniclass”，中文名？

我也不知道。你有翻译么？

回到咱们自己身上来，你是知识工人么？还只是有知识的无产者？在这个时代，在这个社会上，你靠

什么赚钱呢？

你赚的钱用在哪里呢？用来消费？还是用来购买企业年金？你的企业有提供企业年金么？你会买你企

业提供的年金么？

工作这么多年后，你都有哪些资产呢？你的资产中，哪些有助于你未来的生活呢？比如你老年后的生

活？

房子？车子？医疗保单？人寿保单？股票？股权？社保？商业养老保险？年金？

如果你在赚钱，而只有你在赚钱，你的钱并没有融入到这个社会上帮你一起赚钱，那么你就不是一个

“资本家”，只是一个有知识的无产者而已。

你是谁？

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

一小时运动

英文原文

27 OCTOBER

Political Integration of Knowledge Workers

Integration：

整合；一体化

[ U C ] the act or process of combining two or more things so that they work together (= of integrating them)

结合；

Knowledge workers are, to coin a term, “uniclass.”

The new majority, the “knowledge worker,” does not fit any interest-group definition.

majority:

大部分；大多数

[ sing.+sing./pl.v. ] ~ (of sb/sth) the largest part of a group of people or things

Knowledge workers are neither farmers nor labor nor business; they are employees of

organizations.

Yet they are not “proletarians” and do not feel “exploited” as a class.

proletarians:

无产阶级者 无产者

exploited:

N-COUNT A proletarian is a member of the proletariat.

;

V-T If you say that someone is exploiting you, you think that they are treating you unfairly by using your work or ideas

and giving you very little in return.

利用; 剥削

Collectively, they are “capitalists” through their pension funds.

Collectively 共同地，全体地

pension:

jointly, corporately

:an amount of money paid regularly by a government or company to sb who is considered to be too old or too ill/sick to

work

养老金；退休金；抚恤金

Many of them are themselves bosses and have “subordinates.”

Yet they also have a boss themselves. They are not middle-class, either.

They are, to coin a term, “uniclass”—though some of them make more money than others.

It makes absolutely no difference to their social position whether they work for a business, a

hospital, or a university.

Knowledge workers who move from accounting work in a business to accounting work in a hospital

are not changing social or economic position.

They are changing a job.

This status implies no specific economic or social culture.

implies：

V-T If you imply that something is the case, you say something that indicates that it is the case in an indirect way.

So far there is no political concept, no political integration that fits them.

ACTION POINT:

Knowledge workers are capitalists in both the old and new senses.

capitalists：

senses：

基于资本主义原则的

N-COUNT Your senses are the physical abilities of sight, smell, hearing, touch, and taste. 感觉功能

ADJ A capitalist country or system supports or is based on the principles of capitalism.

Do you see any political party addressing the interests of these new capitalists?

The New Realities

暗指

27 OCTOBER

Political Integration of Knowledge Workers

Knowledge workers are, to coin a term, “uniclass.”

The new majority, the “knowledge worker,” does not fit any interest-

group definition. Knowledge workers are neither farmers nor labor nor

business; they are employees of organizations. Yet they are not “proletari-

ans” and do not feel “exploited” as a class. Collectively, they are “capital-

ists” through their pension funds. Many of them are themselves bosses and

have “subordinates.” Yet they also have a boss themselves. They are not

middle-class, either. They are, to coin a term, “uniclass”—though some of

them make more money than others. It makes absolutely no difference to

their social position whether they work for a business, a hospital, or a uni-

versity. Knowledge workers who move from accounting work in a business to

accounting work in a hospital are not changing social or economic posi-

tion. They are changing a job.

This status implies no specific economic or social culture. So far there

is no political concept, no political integration that fits them.

ACTION POINT:

Knowledge workers are capitalists in both the old and new

senses. Do you see any political party addressing the interests of these

new capitalists?

The New Realities

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

乔峰的考量

乔峰本来是契丹人，本名萧峰。杏子林事件解开了乔峰的身世之谜，乔峰也就扔下了打狗棒，离开了

丐帮。

乔峰的身世揭开事件，或者称为杏子林事件，是丐帮副帮主马大元的夫人康敏一手导演的，期目的是

为了毁掉萧峰，控制丐帮，进而和大理对抗。

这些是根本原因，是时候分析的原因。而在当时，有一个直接的原因是乔峰不愿意杀慕容复为马大元

报仇。

马大元死了，死于自己的成名绝技唢喉擒拿手下，这种“以彼之道，还施彼身”的惯例，一向是江南慕

容复的手笔。丐帮的人看到马大元的尸体，仿佛尸体上写上了“杀人者慕容复是也”。

所以，丐帮随即南下，要杀慕容复报仇，丐帮是天下第一大帮，丐帮要向慕容复报仇，即使武功卓越

异常，慕容复也不一定能对付过来，何况还有一个武功高不可测的乔峰主导。慕容复好像必死无疑

了。

不过，乔峰却不想杀慕容复，至少不想这么糊里糊涂地杀。

我认为，这个“不想杀”有几个原因。

首先，乔峰喜欢交朋友，第一次看到段誉后，喝了一顿酒，即结拜为兄弟。何况和自己齐名的慕容

复。“北乔峰，南慕容”，这种江湖上的话语，多少让这位北方汉子对慕容复有些神交。所以，乔峰的

本意是想和慕容复交朋友的。

其次，乔峰来到江南后，遇到慕容复的两个下属：公冶乾和风波恶，乔峰认为这两个人都是光明磊落

的汉子。乔峰认为，物以类聚，人以群分，既然公冶乾和风波恶这么光明磊落，慕容复也不应该卑鄙

滥杀之人。

这两个是表面的意思，其实，还有一层意思，乔峰没有说出来，不过，我认为这才是真正的原因。因

为前两个原因都是乔峰自身的原因，而第三个原因，则是丐帮的原因。

丐帮是天下第一大帮，乔峰是北乔峰；慕容家是江南武术世家，慕容复是南慕容，两方实力都不容小

觑。如果两方真打起来，肯定是“伤敌一千，自损八百”。

如果是为了给自己的兄弟报仇，受苦，受累也就认了，可是，如果是被别人挑唆，被别人陷害呢？

北乔峰和南慕容一被挑逗，就打了起来，打个你死我活？最后谁获益？

北乔峰 KO 南慕容，丐帮 KO 慕容家，这肯定是一件影响武林格局的大战，对于这样一场大战，肯定不

能只凭只言片语，甚至猜测就直接杀了起来。

毕竟，丐帮虽然只是一些叫花子的集合，却也是天下第一大帮，作为丐帮帮主的乔峰，不只是要考虑

自己丐帮的利益、情绪，自己的利益和情绪，还要考虑武林的整体。

从这个角度来看，乔峰是一个很合格的政治家，虽然他只是一个叫化头。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

28 OCTOBER

The Corporation as a Political Institution

In dealing with constituencies outside the primary task, managers have to think politically.

When it comes to the performance of the primary task of an institution—whether economic goods

and services in the case of the business, health care in that of a hospital, or scholarship and higher

education in that of the university—the rule is to optimize.

There, managers have to base their decisions on what is right rather than on what is acceptable.

But in dealing with the constituencies outside and beyond this narrow definition of the primary

task, managers have to think politically—in terms of the minimum needed to placate and appease

and keep quiet constituent groups that otherwise might use their power of veto. Managers cannot

be politicians.

They cannot confine themselves to “satisficing” decisions. But they also cannot be concerned only

with optimization in the central area of performance of their institution.

They have to balance both approaches in one continuous decision-making progress.

The corporation is an economic institution.

But it is also a political institution.

Managers have to think through what the constituencies are that can effectively veto and block

decisions, and what their minimum expectations and needs should be.

ACTION POINT:

List the constituents of your enterprise.

constituents：

ADJ The constituent parts of something are the things from which it is formed.

构成的

Next, list how you plan to optimize the needs of your customers and meet at least the minimum

expectations of each of the other constituents.

A Functioning Society

28 OCTOBER

The Corporation as a Political Institution

In dealing with constituencies outside the primary task,

managers have to think politically.

When it comes to the performance of the primary task of an institu-tion

—whether economic goods and services in the case of the busi-ness, health

care in that of a hospital, or scholarship and higher education

in that of the university—the rule is to optimize. There, managers have to

base their decisions on what is right rather than on what is acceptable. But

in dealing with the constituencies outside and beyond this narrow defini-

tion of the primary task, managers have to think politically—in terms of

the minimum needed to placate and appease and keep quiet constituent

groups that otherwise might use their power of veto. Managers cannot be

politicians. They cannot confine themselves to “satisficing” decisions.

But they also cannot be concerned only with optimization in the central

area of performance of their institution. They have to balance both

approaches in one continuous decision-making progress. The corporation

is an economic institution. But it is also a political institution.

Managers have to think through what the constituencies are that can

ef-fectively veto and block decisions, and what their minimum

expectations and needs should be.

ACTION POINT:

List the constituents of your enterprise. Next, list how you

plan to optimize the needs of your customers and meet at least the min-

imum expectations of each of the other constituents.

A Functioning Society

透过金庸读懂德鲁克

颜回穷么？

我们有个论语群，论语群里每天讨论论语相关的话题。前几天大家讨论了一个话题：颜回穷么？

颜回在儒家的地位非常高，被称为复圣。十三岁拜孔子为师，终生师事之，是孔子最得意的门生。孔

子对颜回称赞最多，赞其好学仁人。

孔子的有弟子三千，其中有七十二人被称为贤人。而颜回是七十二贤人之首。

大家对颜回的主要记忆有两个，一是早亡，一是贫穷。

颜回生于公元前521年，死于公元前481年，享年40岁。这个年龄在现在肯定算早亡，在春秋末期呢？

肯定不能算早亡，只是和孔子比早了点，孔子活了73岁。

那么，颜回穷么？咱们看看论语中对颜回的记载。

《论语·雍也第六》:“一箪食，一瓢饮，在陋巷，人不堪其忧，回也不改其乐 。贤哉回也!”

这是孔子对颜回的描述，描述的是颜回吃的很简单，喝的也也很简单，住的也简单，在这种其他人没

法接受的环境下，颜回还是很开心。

我的理解，这里只是孔子说了颜回对物质生活要求比较低。而且在这种比较低的环境下，颜回很快

乐，也就是说颜回 “甘贫乐道”。我认为，孔子强调的是颜回的“乐”，而不是贫。

那么颜回都有哪些资产呢？庄子中记载了孔子和颜回的一次对话：

孔子谓颜回曰：“回，来！家贫居卑，胡不仕乎？”

颜回对曰：“不愿仕。回有郭外之田五十亩，足以给飦粥；郭内之田四十亩，足以为丝麻；鼓琴足以自

娱，所学夫子之道者足以自乐也。回不愿仕。”

孔子愀然变容曰：“善哉回之意！丘闻之：’知足者不以利自累也，审自得者失之而不惧，行修于内者无

位而不怍。’丘诵之久矣，今于回而后见之，是丘之得也。”

孔子问颜回：“回呀，你这么穷，为啥不出去做官呢？”

颜回说：“我不愿意做官，我在城外有50亩地，足够吃了；我在城里还有40亩地，也足够织麻布做衣

服了。我自己弹琴，就可以娱乐，我跟着老师学习道理，也就可以很快乐了。所以，我不愿意做官。”

是呀，颜回说的很清楚，颜回没必要做官（来赚钱养活自己），城里城外都有地。还会弹琴自娱自

乐，还可以跟着当世最好的老师（孔子）学习。这些已经是完美的生活了。所以，颜回不需要做官。

从这个对话可以看出，颜回是不缺钱的。

其实，这里还有一个很重要的细节，就是颜回是孔子的弟子。你可以要知道，孔子的主要职业是老

师，而且这个老师是收学费的，而且不便宜：“自行束脩以上，吾未尝无诲焉。”（你只要送我10条肉

干，我就教你）

颜回十三岁就跟着孔子学习，终身师事之，这二十多年，也不少条肉干呢。

要知道，在古代，读书可不是穷人可以做到的。

所以说，颜回或许并不富，但绝不穷。只是颜回甘贫而已，这也是孔子赞扬颜回的地方。

咱们换一个角度看，孔子收学生10条肉干，3000个学生，就是30000条肉干，就算一天吃一条肉干，

也可以吃30000天。也就是可以吃82年。孔子享寿73岁，所以，孔子也是不穷的。

我一个朋友说过一句话：“你说没钱，是没有买房子的钱，而我说没钱，是没有吃饭的钱。”

这才是本质。

那么，孔子为什么要收学费呢？作为教育家，难道不应该尽可能为更多人提供教育机会么？为什么要

通过学费来过滤掉那些真正的穷学生呢？

这就是一个很重要的观点了。提升普通人的学识水平，这是一个很好的事情，这样的好事情，这样的

好事情广而告之，会有人把孩子送来么？当然会，却不会多。这会有几个问题。

首先，是没钱，孔子把时间用在教书上，就没有时间去种地去做其他的事情了。所以，孔子需要一些

收入来维持生活。

其次，如果孔子不收学费，大家则会怀疑孔子的目的：要找免费劳力？要拉你入邪教？要你“依师”？

所以，还是收费来的实在。

当然，如果你确实想学，而确实没钱，我才孔子也肯定教的。毕竟大部分人教学费已经把孔子的生活

费问题解决了。

所以，收学费才是孔子收到3000个学生的一个主要驱动力。

大纲

百字摘要

金庸案例

时间消耗

阅读理解：

大纲：

撰写：

录音

一小时运动

英文原文

29 OCTOBER

Converting Good Intentions into Results

“It’s much easier to sell the Brooklyn Bridge than to give it away.”

The nonprofit institution is not merely delivering a service.

It wants the end user to be not a user but a doer.

It uses a service to bring about a change in human beings.

It attempts to become a part of the recipient rather than merely a supplier.

recipient：( formal ) a person who receives sth 受方；接受者

supplier：a person or company that supplies goods 供应者；供货商；供货方

Nonprofit institutions used to think they didn’t need marketing.

But, as a famous old saying by a great nineteenth-century con man has it, “It’s much easier to sell

the Brooklyn Bridge than to give it away.”

con： [ sing. ] ( also BrE also formal ˈconfidence trick ) ( also NAmE also formalˈconfidence game ) a trick; an act of cheating

sb 诡计；骗局；欺骗

Nobody trusts you if you offer something for free.

You need to market even the most beneficial service.

But the marketing you do in the nonprofit sector is quite different from selling.

It’s more a matter of looking at your service from the recipient’s point of view.

You have to know what to sell, to whom to sell, and when to sell.

ACTION POINT:

The mission of the Salvation Army is to make citizens out of the rejected.

Salvation：( in Christianity 基督教 ) the state of being saved from the power of evil 得救；救恩；救世

rejected：V-T If you reject something such as a proposal, a request, or an offer, you do not accept it or you do not agree to

it. 拒绝; 不同意

How does that service look from the recipient’s point of view?

How should the Salvation Army market that service?

Managing the Non-Profit Organization

【原书原文】

Converting Good

Intentions into Results

The non-profit institution is not merely delivering a service. It wants the end user to be not a user but a doer. It uses a

service to bring about change in a human being. In that sense a school, for instance, is quite different from Procter &

Gamble. It creates habits, vision, commitment, knowledge. It attempts to become a part of the recipient rather than

merely a supplier. Until this has happened, the non-profit institution has had no results; it has only had good

intentions.

Napoleon said that there were three things needed to fight a war. The first is money The second is money. And the

third is money. That may be true for war, but it’s not true for the non-profit organization. There you need four things.

You need a plan. You need marketing. You need people. And you need money.

The plan we have just talked about, in the first part. People we will be talking about a little later, in this book’s fourth

and fifth parts. In this part we talk about the strategies that convert the plan into results. How do we get our service to

the ”customer/ that is, to the community we exist to serve? How do we market it? And how do we get the money we

need to provide the service?

Non-profit institutions that do well used to think they didn’t need marketing. But, as a famous old saying by a great

nineteenth-century con man has it, ’It much easier to sell the Brooklyn Bridge than to give it away/ Nobody trusts you if

you offer something for free. You need to market even the most beneficial service. But the marketing you do in the
